https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107512,2022,Supervised Machine Learning,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. PC Schoonees', 'prof.dr. PJF Groenen']",,"Inhoud
Instructors: prof. dr. P.J.F. Groenen (EUR), dr. P. Schoonees (EUR).

Statistical learning methods arising from statistics, machine learning, and data science have become more widespread available. Machine learning methods can be split in supervised learning with the aim of predicting a response variable and unsupervised learning describing the relations between all variables simultaneously. This course focusses on supervised learning and has as its goal that the student obtains a thorough technical understanding of selection of supervised machine learning techniques, can choose between them sensibly, can implement the technique in a high level language such as R, python, Julia, or Octave, and can write a report about the technique.

The book of Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman (2001, 1st edition) has been a milestone in connecting statistical ideas into machine learning techniques. Parts of this book will form the basis of this course. A tentative overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are a selection of linear methods for regression, linear methods for classification, basis expansion and regularization, model assessment and selection, classification and regression trees, ensemble learning (random forests, bagging, and bosting), regularized generalized canonical correlation analysis, partial least-squares, and support vector machines.</body>

<body>To understanding the fundamental building blocks of several machine learning methods, being able to choose from them, being able to program these methods, and being able to apply them sensibly.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106106,2022,Supply Chain Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Tekin'],,"Inhoud

Supply chains are complex networks of organizations that supply and transform materials, and distribute final products and services to customers. Managing a supply change is a big challenge as well as an opportunity for both manufacturing and service industries. For a well designed and properly managed supply chain, firms must combine internal and external information in a dynamic fashion and focus on models, analytic tools to predict the future and gain a competitive advantage.

This course focuses on models and analytical tools to design and operate an effective supply chain. It adopts modern forecasting and machine learning methods to improve the performance of a supply chain while reducing the total cost. Students will have hands-on experience on real life applications of data analytics (descriptive, predictive, prescriptive) applied to several supply chain management topics such as
• value of information and bullwhip effect in supply chains,
R programming language will be widely used for solving the assignments.

This course explores models and effective analytics tools to design a successful supply chain. Demand forecasting and inventory management are two fundamental topics of supply chain analysis. In terms of demand forecasting, students will learn how to accurately predict the number of items to be sold next week/month/year based on a historical sales data. The mathematical and econometrics tools (i.e. time series analysis) will prove useful to forecast future demand. Once demand is estimated accurately, the next step is the inventory management. Here, several replenishment methods will be studied. In the remaining period, other relevant topics of supply chain management such as revenue management will also be discussed. At the end of the course students will:
• Be able to examine and improve the supply chain operations such as flow of materials through a network of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors and retailers,
• Be familiar with managing uncertainty in supply chains,
• Understand tradeoffs to manage inventories in real world,
• Familiarize themselves with analytical tools and models for effective solutions to problems in managing a supply chain,
• Address the analytical challenges arising in supply chains.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106269,2022,Supply Chain Decision Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Lemmens', 'E Aghamohammadzadeh, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Success in a complex supply chain environment depends on your ability to make good decisions. This requires a systematic, data-driven and fact-based approach to decision-making and problem analysis. The same philosophy is also at the heart of scientific research. This course teaches you a variety of tools for business analytics and optimization modelling. You will explore the research that aims to solve decision problems in the supply chain management. Moreover, this course will prepare you for your thesis project, which starts in January.
Upon completion of this course students are prepared to:
• Solve business decision problems via optimization modelling
• Implement optimization models and approaches in CPLEX

The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company
column2: in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process
column3: furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.

column1: To pass this core course, a participant needs to:
<li>Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade)
• Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).

Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:
• Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
• Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations

• Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
• Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
• Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
• Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
• Enhance your team working and project management skills

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107673,2022,Supply Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

Companies have over time specialized in a very limited number of business activities which they consider to be their core business. By doing so, they have been able to greatly increase their expertise, innovative capabilities and process efficiency. Companies have subsequently located their operations in regions that are most suitable in terms of natural resources, labor (either cheap or high grade), sales markets etc. As a consequence, a long chain of companies is involved in the manufacturing of products. These companies have limited insight into each other’s operations, and are often dispersed around the world. Such a situation requires that the chain of companies is effectively managed otherwise processes would falter, customers would have to be disappointed, and costs would surge. Therefore, supply chain management is vital to companies that operate in such chains. Proper planning and managing of the supply chain can make the difference between a successful business and an outright failure.

Progress in information technology has contributed to both the increasing need and opportunities for improved supply chain management. With IT, companies in a supply chain can be connected in real-time, which allows for efficient and effective sharing of information.

The course program presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, planning, control and improvement of supply chain operations.
The course Supply Chain Management builds on the knowledge obtained in the course Operations Management offered in Bachelor 1.</body>

In this course students are not only encouraged to acquire the necessary knowledge, but also to develop a critical attitude to the position of firms in relation to various strategic and operational choices related to the supply chain.
<li>make you conversant in the language of supply chain management
<li>allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations
<li>enhance your critical thinking, not only in the area supply chain management but also as a future general manager
• provide you with qualitative and quantitative tools to identify, analyze, and manage basic supply chain management issues.
At the end of the course the student should be able to:
<li>identify and use the main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management
<li>select and use the appropriate instruments and tools to construct a supply chain management solution for a given situation
<li>identify and describe the needed design features of the supply chain
<li>recognize and use the different inventory replenishment strategies to control inventory levels
<li>clarify and leverage the value of information sharing as assisted by information technology for the integrated supply chain
<li>describe and choose the correct purchasing and sourcing strategy dependent on the features of a supply chain
<li>design the physical distribution in a supply chain and adopt the transportation accordingly
<li>identify the different (strategic) constructs for parties of the supply chain to collaborate, and to discuss and mitigate the accompanying risks
• analyse cases of real world situations and develop suitable supply chain management solutions.
Before taking this course it is strongly recommended that you have a firm grasp on the following concepts:
• Some knowledge of Marketing, Information and Organizational management.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108904,2022,Supply Chain Simulation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. GG Loke'],,"Inhoud

Modern supply chain management involves decision making in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environments. This course focuses on the use of simulation techniques to make better supply chain decisions under such conditions. For that purpose, the course combines relevant theoretical knowledge with application of simulation techniques with the help of computer-based tools. In particular, we shall focus on discrete event simulations. In all cases, we represent real-life supply chains using computer models. These models serve as a safe playground to study and evaluate supply chain decision making, allowing us to gain essential insights into how supply chain performance may be improved.

The course is divided into (mandatory) lectures in which students will learn the theoretical basics, and (mandatory) workshops, where students will learn how to build simulation models in Arena. The grade is based on three assignments. The lab sessions give students the opportunity to ask questions on the assignments.
In this course, students will learn how to use, build, and interpret simulation models of processes to analyze them and to support decision making.
After completing this course, you will be able to
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Understand and apply the key concepts of discrete event simulations
• Analyze input data for use in a simulation model
• Run experiments with a simulation model
• Analyze the output of a simulation model and draw conclusions on the process modelled
• Understand the concept of decision making under uncertainty
• Gain insight into how the quality of a solution is affected by unknown factors and by an unknown future

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107659,2022,Supply chain management,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

Bedrijven zijn zich in toenemende mate gaan specialiseren op een beperkt aantal kernactiviteiten (de zogenaamde ‘core business’). Door deze specialisatie zijn bedrijven in staat om op hun deelgebied veel kennis op te bouwen, innovatieve producten te ontwikkelen en efficiënt te werken. Bedrijven vestigen zich op locaties die voor hun specialisme het meest geschikt zijn. Dit kan zijn vanwege de beschikbaarheid van grondstoffen, goedkope of juist hoogwaardige arbeidskrachten, belangrijke afzetmarkten, etc. Als gevolg van deze specialisatie is een lange keten van bedrijven betrokken bij de fabricage van een eindproduct. Bedrijven die vaak een beperkt inzicht hebben in elkaars activiteiten en die verspreid over de hele wereld kunnen zitten. Een dergelijke situatie vereist dat de keten van bedrijven goed gemanaged wordt omdat anders de processen vastlopen, klanten teleurgesteld moeten worden en kosten hoog oplopen. Supply chain management is daarom van cruciaal belang voor bedrijven die zich in dergelijke ketens bevinden. Het plannen en managen van de supply chain kan het verschil maken tussen een succesvol bedrijf en een complete mislukking.

De vooruitgang in informatietechnologie heeft bijgedragen aan zowel de stijgende behoefte als aan de toenemende kansen voor een verbeterd supply chain management. Met behulp van IT kunnen bedrijven hun supply chain koppelen aan real-time informatie en kan op een effectieve en efficiënte manier kennis gedeeld worden.
In dit vak worden verscheidene bedrijfscases gepresenteerd die vragen om state-of-the-art modellen en oplossingsmethoden voor ontwerp, planning, beheersing en verbetering van supply chains.
Het vak Supply Chain Management bouwt voort op de kennis die verkregen is in het vak Primaire Processen (Bachelor 1).</body>

Dit vak moedigt studenten aan niet alleen de vereiste kennis te vergaren, maar ook om een kritische houding te verwerven ten aanzien van de positie van bedrijven in relatie tot de verschillende strategische en operationele keuzes gerelateerd aan de supply chain.
Het vak streeft er naar om:
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student de taal van supply chain management te laten begrijpen en gebruiken
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student inzicht te geven in de rol die supply chain management speelt in de bedrijfsstrategie en de prestaties van de organisatie
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student kritisch te laten kijken en denken over zowel supply chain management als andere aspecten van het managen van een organisatie
• de student te voorzien van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve tools om hem in staat te stellen eenvoudige supply chain management vraagstukken te identificeren, analyseren en op te lossen.
Aan het eind van het vak moeten de studenten in staat zijn om:
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de belangrijkste concepten en terminologie uit het supply chain management vakgebied te benoemen en te gebruiken
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de juiste instrumenten en methoden te kiezen en te gebruiken om een supply chain management oplossing te genereren voor een bepaald probleem
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de ontwerpkenmerken van de supply chain te benoemen en uit te leggen
• de verschillende voorspellingsmethoden in supply chain management toe te passen
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de verschillende voorraadbestelstrategieën te herkennen en te gebruiken om voorraadniveaus te beheersen
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de waarde van informatiedeling duidelijk te maken en te gebruiken, ondersteund door informatie technologie voor de geïntegreerde supply chain
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de juiste inkoop- en sourcingstrategieën te beschrijven en te kiezen afhankelijk van de kenmerken van een supply chain
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de fysieke distributie in een supply chain in te richten en het transport hierop aan te passen
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de verschillende (strategische) samenwerkingsvormen te benoemen tussen partijen in een supply chain en de bijbehorende risico’s te identificeren en te reduceren
• echte bedrijfscases te analyseren en hiervoor gepaste supply chain oplossingen te ontwikkelen.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106568,2022,Surveillance and Societies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Trottier'],,"Inhoud

Surveillance denotes the collection of personal information for purposes of control. It is a primary organising logic among states and organisations, but also activists and other individuals. Surveillance involves the use of emerging technologies, as well as longstanding forms of management and governance, in order to make the social world knowable and assert a particular social order.

This course aims to situate surveillance practices in diverse institutions, in order to recognise their social, cultural and communicative purpose in contemporary societies. This course treats surveillance as a topic that garners public concern, with the goal of contributing to theoretical and empirical accounts to these understandings.

Students will consider surveillance practices across institutional and cultural contexts. This will involve applying concepts and assumptions to a range of developments. Each week addresses a particular context in which surveillance occurs, and bridges digitally mediated with embodied practices. Students will participate in and occasionally lead discussions on particular forms of surveillance, and their social, cultural, informational and ethical dimensions and implications.</body>
- Foundational conceptual frameworks and theoretical perspectives about surveillance practices across social contexts
- Historically and culturally situated accounts of information technologies
- Apply concepts and empirical insights about surveillance practices to relevant contexts, notably linking emerging cases with historic precedents
- Appraise public discourses in order to interpret how surveillance practices are shaped and normalised
- Critically engage with surveillance studies scholarship to consider its relevance to digital media and communication studies</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107422,2022,Surveillance and the Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. D Trottier', 'Q Huang']",,"Inhoud

New technologies and related practices are a source of excitement, anxiety and inspiration. This is especially the case when these technologies are used to monitor people, or allow those people to monitor others. Shared understandings of emerging and controversial technologies are shaped by popular media representations in entertainment. Science-fiction, sitcoms and song lyrics (among other sources) provide coherent and lasting accounts of what it feels like to watch or be watched. Moreover, the way we watch others through media such as reality television and live-streaming also shapes our understanding of what kinds of surveillance are acceptable.

This course explores the role of the media in accounting for surveillance practices and digitalisation. This includes a historic and multi-cultural overview of the viewer society. Upon discussing and engaging with relevant concepts and methodological approaches, students will carry out small scale empirical analysis of media content.
Students have knowledge and understanding of:
• Theoretical frameworks and concepts that enable understandings of representations of surveillance practices.
• Analyse and interpret media documents in terms of qualitative and culturally situated analytic frameworks.
• Report on their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.
• Critically reflect on methodological limitations and possible societal implications of their research.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106493,2022,Surveillance in Film, TV, and Media Platforms",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AG Fokkema'],,"Inhoud

The course’s primary focus is the representation of surveillance and intelligence on screen (TV/streaming services, film, and, to some extent, documentary). A working concept will be that surveillance and intelligence are related concepts and that it is worth exploring the historical dimensions of these concepts. The theoretical literature is mainly concerned with the social, philosophical, and media perspectives on surveillance and intelligence. In the seminar we will see how developments in surveillance techniques give rise to questions about the price of information gathering. We shall treat SF movies, TV series and documentaries as reflecting contemporary concerns with surveillance and intelligence. Black Mirror episodes are an obvious reference point, but think also of a film like Das Leben der Anderen.

column9: Students will have gained insight into course relevant theoretical debates on surveillance and intelligence
Students can compare and contrast the representation of surveillance and intelligence in film, documentary, and TV in an international perspective
Students can relate the relevant theoretical issues to such representations

column1: - MEP-CK020s Biostatistics I Spring and PHDCO-014 R Course (Module II)
For questions about the requirements, please contact Prof. dr. Dimitris Rizopoulos:&nbsp

This course presents methods for the statistical analysis of time-to-event data, also known as survival data. The course begins by explaining the unique features of this data that invalidate the use of standard statistical tools. Then, alternative descriptive and inferential analysis techniques are introduced, including the Kaplan-Meier estimator, the log-rank test for censored data, and the Cox proportional hazards model. Finally, the course closes by presenting the stratified Cox model and how to handle competing risks.&nbsp
column2: During the course, the participants will learn to use R to perform survival analysis and interpret the obtained results correctly.&nbsp
column3: Participants must have followed Introduction to Biostatistics (Module I) and R course (Module II) and need this module to follow the course on prediction models (module IV).&nbsp
column4: Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.&nbsp
column5: You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109093,2022,Sustainability Accounting and Reporting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Choi, MSc']",,"Inhoud

In many countries and industries, sustainability accounting is now acknowledged as an essential process of business operation where companies develop measures for their environmental, social, and governance performances
column4: and assist managers in making critical decisions for their companies and society. However, adopting and implementing such a complex managerial system has become more and more challenging as the demand from stakeholders for responsible business has grown substantially during the past decades as well. This course offers a comprehensive overview of managerial processes involved in sustainability accountability. Students will learn basic concepts, theories and practices and be given opportunities to apply their knowledge and critical thinking to evaluating sustainability reports and standards.</body>

column1: The goal of this course is to broaden students’ understanding of sustainability accountability. At the end of the course, students will be able to:
• Recognize the distinguishable processes through which sustainability is measured, assured, and reported.
• Examine various types of sustainability measurement/reporting standards
• Explain the typical challenges faced by companies regarding sustainability accounting

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106512,2022,Sustainability Communication: Systemic Approaches,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. R Mittal'],,"Inhoud

<body>Communicating sustainability effectively is of critical importance in a world where multiple socio-environmental concerns impact and disrupt everyday life. Aligning with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, this course explores some key sustainability narratives and communication challenges. We will study the role of the media and other critical actors while examining actionable messaging techniques and communication strategies. Participants will undertake hands-on approaches to both identify sustainability communication challenges and develop related communication solutions and strategies.</body>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:
• Understand complex, environment-specific media discourses and their influence on public perception
• Evaluate and critically reflect on gaps in sustainability communication and barriers to effective environmental messaging
• Apply theoretical insights and developments in communication best practices to evaluate contemporary examples and cases
• Create actionable communication strategies to support issue-specific sustainability transformations

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106024,2022,Sustainability Ethics & Sustainable Behaviour,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'L Versteegt, MSc', 'LDM De Schutter, MSc', 'prof.dr. SP Kaptein']",,"Inhoud

With the global population growing to 9.7 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, organizations need to drive the transition toward a sustainable society, one that does not transgress planetary boundaries and where value is created for all stakeholders involved, including nature and future generations.

This global challenge elicits questions about (a) what managers, companies and stakeholders ought to do, and (b) how they can be moved to actually act like this. Put differently, this course offers (a) a normative focus on sustainability and (b) a descriptive focus on how to motivate sustainable behaviour.

Normative, more philosophical questions include how companies ought to treat their stakeholders, when is it right to prioritize environmental outcomes over social outcomes, how much ought we weight outcomes of future generations and how much should we rely on technological solutions. Descriptive, more behavioural questions include how consumers can be encouraged to buy green products, how managers can end up acting in immoral ways that nullify sustainable progress, what psychological barriers to sustainable behaviour people may experience, and why managers may be tempted to act in their self-interest, rather than the collective interest.

Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, normative stakeholder theory, greenwashing, green consumerism, social dilemmas and environmental ethics. We will focus also on your own moral development and explore your own sustainability values, while reflecting on barriers in realizing them.

This course emphasizes linking theory, research and practice, and therefore so do the course assignments. While the assignments are still tentative, the first assignment that is planned is for you and your team to either (a) carry out a quantitative, applied research project on a topic relevant to sustainability and ethics, or (b) conduct research using CSR-reporting from companies to identify and provide solutions for moral challenges that these companies are facing. Both assignments will allow you to further apply theory and literature on sustainability and ethics, as well as to subject your own ideas to (empirical) scrutiny, and to communicate your findings concisely, accurately, clearly and straightforwardly in a paper of 2500 words maximum. You and your team will also present your research to your fellow students, allowing you to further practice communicating your ideas.

The second assignment consists of an individual 1000-word essay where you will reflect on material from at least two different lectures. This gives you the opportunity to creatively process the course material. Perhaps you see previously unimagined potential in some of the theories discussed in the lectures, allowing you to propose brand new applications for sustainable development in business. Perhaps you see ways to improve existing theories and make them more relevant to practice. Or perhaps you are skeptical of certain theories, the link between theory and practice, or the value of the empirical research discussed in the lectures.
This course consists of six lectures, two consultation sessions, and one presentation session. Active participation during the lectures may count toward one’s final grade.</body>
• To analyze sustainability dilemmas from an ethical viewpoint.
• To understand what drives sustainable (moral) behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole.
• To become more self-aware of one’s sustainable values and moral development.
• To translate theory and research on sustainability ethics and sustainable behaviour into real-world interventions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106026,2022,Sustainability Grand Challenges,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. M De Moor'],,"Inhoud

column3: focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to&nbsp
column5: as well as social problems. Examples include&nbsp
column6: climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty and inequality. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand,&nbsp

column3: will collaborate to analyze a sustainability grand challenge and formulate&nbsp
column5: by engaging multiple partners and by thinking out-of-the-box.&nbsp
column9: together to create a novel and&nbsp

column12: main learning goal of this course is&nbsp

column1: You will work individually as well as in teams and under significant time pressures to analyze the grand challenge and jointly formulate a credible and feasible ‘solution’. You will individually demonstrate your understanding of the grand challenge with an individual essay and by reviewing one of your peers, and jointly develop and assess a solution in a group report. You will present the solution in the group report to a multi-stakeholder jury at the end of the course. Your groups will need to apply your learning of structuring and delivery of a message in time-restricted and context-sensitive ‘pitching’ format for this presentation.
After completing this course, students are able to:
• Evaluate the sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks on wicked problems, temporality and scale
• Jointly analyze the stakeholders related to the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly develop a solution to harness the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly reflect on the viability of the developed solution
• Jointly deliver a convincing pitch suitable for the boardroom.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106022,2022,Sustainability Leadership and Planetary Boundaries,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. SP Kennedy', 'JAJ Batenburg - Suijker']",,"Inhoud

Our world is facing severe global social and environmental challenges. Human population is growing, while the resource base it relies on for wellbeing continues to decline. We have surpassed the ecological thresholds of some of the planetary boundaries that govern a safe space for humanity, while others are being encroached with short windows of opportunity for solutions. Basic needs of many of the world’s people remain unmet, while inequality has grown to the extent that the world’s richest 62 people are worth more than the poorest 50% of the world’s global population.

Sustainability has now long been a boardroom agenda, yet our ecological systems continue to degrade and many social issues remain unresolved. The reality check for business leadership is that nine billion people simply cannot live well in this world if companies do not start finding new solutions to co-create a safe operating space for humanity. In this course we consider how business leaders are taking this challenge seriously.

The goal of this course is to broaden participants’ understanding of sustainability, allowing for a holistic recognition of the interconnectivity of issues and their impacts on the future of business. Participants will learn the basics concepts of corporate sustainability and the meaning of ‘true corporate sustainability’ from a holistic and embedded perspective. The course engages with how and why companies form sustainability strategies and considers how an embedded perspective can be achieved through tools such as the planetary boundaries framework. Participants will be immersed in how strategies may be implemented through a range of the contemporary advancements in sustainability leadership such as sustainable business models, integrated reporting and the circular economy.
Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.

The course is 6 ECTS and only four weeks in duration. The course is not designed for students to be taking any parallel courses at the same time. Each week requires the full attention of students as it has multiple weekly plenary sessions, weekly readings, weekly assignments and weekly a seminar to attend.

Seminars will be 2-hours in length and will be held each Friday. All students are assigned a weekly seminar group that occurs at the same time each week. This may be found under the ‘People’ tab on the Canvas site. Seminars are held at 09.00-10.45, 11.00-12.45 and 15.00-16.45 on Fridays

Each seminar requires you to prepare in advance either individually or as part of a group. Preparation for all the seminars need to be submitted in advance of the session, deadline 22.00 CEST the day before the seminar will be held (Thursday). For Week 1 and Week 4, every student needs to submit their own individual seminar exercise. For Week 2 and 3, the exercise is completed as a group and only one group member needs to submit. Seminars will focus on discussing the answers to the weekly exercises
After following this course, the student is able to:
• Explain business sustainability from a holistic and embedded perspective.
• Analyse how and why sustainability challenges occur within social-ecological systems.
• Explain how firms can use systems and resilience thinking to effectively change how social-ecological systems behave.
• Apply systems thinking to create business models for sustainability.
• Evaluate organizational responses to sustainability challenges from a systems perspective.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106349,2022,Sustainability in the Visual Arts and Crafts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AMC Brandellero', 'U Hahn, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course provides an introduction to and application of key concepts and developments in thinking about sustainability in contemporary societies and cities, covering environmental, social and economic dimensions. From the early conceptualizations of sustainable development to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, from the Anthropocene to the climate crisis, from the doughnut and circular economy to green growth and greenwashing – we will start by reviewing and critically assessing the contribution of different concepts to contemporary societal challenges. Then we will apply these concepts to an exploration of sustainable practices in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts, mapping out key developments in production, consumption and communication. We will critically&nbsp
column3: the potential of small-scale urban making and crafts to offer solutions for sustainable forms of production and consumption practices, exploring opportunities and potential pitfalls.&nbsp
column4: Moreover, we will appraise the role that the&nbsp
column5: visual arts can play in addressing sustainability topics, and we will explore what (un)sustainable practices can occur in the (visual) arts world.&nbsp
column6: By the end of this course, students will have the ability to reproduce and critically discuss some of the most influential concepts and approaches to sustainable development in contemporary visual arts and crafts</body>

column1: This course offers an introduction to notions and debates around sustainability in contemporary societies and applies these notions to an exploration of sustainable practices in crafts and the visual arts. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to:
• Recognize and explain central concepts and debates in contemporary theoretical and policy approaches to sustainability
• Analyse key sustainability trends in the production, consumption and communication practices, notably in the fields of the visual arts and crafts
• Critically assess sustainability concepts and apply them to case studies in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107282,2022,Sustainable Development in Historical Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. V Baptist']",,"Inhoud

This course starts from societal challenges in the contemporary global world. It is a course in Applied History and teaches students how students can use history to solve so-called wicked problems. The Sustainable Development Goals identify a couple of such problems which will be studied later on in this course from a historical perspective. The starting-point is the seminal History Manifesto by Jo Guldi and David Armitage. Two concepts will help students to understand how historians can help to solve wicked problems such as gender equality, climate change, poverty, hunger and world peace. Historical analogies show how people in the past dealt with similar problems, while path-dependent evolutions make clear that it will take a radical change to alter deep-rooted historical developments. This course starts from historical reasoning but combines this with case studies about sustainable development.
• Students are able to critically assess the advantages and limitations of applied history
• Students can use theories and methodologies from applied history to analyse contemporary global challenges
• Students can write policy papers to propose solutions for contemporary global challenges based on historical knowledge
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109932,2022,Sustainable Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. D Schoenmaker'],,"Inhoud

Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is the grand challenge of our time. This course gives insight in ‘how finance can contribute to sustainable development’ and aims to inspire PhD researchers to do research in this field.

The finance transition is about transforming finance from operating on financial value only to working with the concept of integrated value, which combines financial, social and ecological value. The concept of integrated value is approached from an academic angle: how to incorporate social and ecological factors in the cost of capital, the valuation and capital structure of companies?
Students apply the integrated value concept in a group assignment or research proposal.</body>
<body>At the end of this course, students should be able to:
• Identify value creation (and destruction) across financial, social and ecological capital
• Establish risk and return profiles for all types of capital
• Know how fundamental equity valuation brings a deeper understanding of companies
• Make capital structure calculations for all types of capital
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108828,2022,Sustainable Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. D Schoenmaker'],,"Inhoud

This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company business models and strategies, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on ESG factors.</body>

Students will learn to critically review the externalities embedded in sustainability challenges, to link climate change science with the evolution of financial markets, and to identify the sustainability risks and opportunities for financial professionals. In terms of applications, students will gain knowledge of the main metrics and financial instruments related to sustainability, and of the techniques to measure and manage the exposure of investment and lending portfolios.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109247,2022,Sustainable Research: Beginner's guide to make your research more environmentally friendly,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['G. Dankova', 'L.A.A. Giannini', 'P. Haro Angles']",,"Inhoud

One of the biggest challenges of our time is to transform our society into one where sustainability and planetary responsibility are seen as core engines for progress and development. This transformation is needed to reduce the impact that climate change has on the lives and livelihoods of people and ecosystems all over the world, such as loss of biodiversity or more frequent and intense droughts, storms and heat waves.&nbsp

Scientific research has a significant environmental footprint. Even though scientists constitute 0.1% of the world’s population, they produce approximately 2% of all plastic waste. Other substantial sources of environmental footprint from the research field are energy consumption from lab equipment and IT, chemical and biological waste, water usage, and travelling to meetings and conferences. Globally, 4.4% of the greenhouse gas emissions is produced by the healthcare sector.

Fortunately, there are ways to reduce this environmental footprint, and each of us can contribute by making our research more environmentally friendly! If you are worried about the amount of plastic waste you produce with your daily activities in the lab, or you wondered about how to reduce energy consumption while running analyses the whole day on your computer, join us in this interactive workshop.
get hands-on ‘green’ tips applicable in both wet-lab and dry-lab research, as well as in your daily life
get to know the community of scientists taking action for research sustainability across the Erasmus MC, the Netherlands and internationally
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.&nbsp
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.&nbsp

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. We have made the evaluation a mandatory part of the course in order to avoid selection bias in the outcomes, and to make sure every student is heard.   &nbsp

On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.&nbsp
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the <a href=""mailto:graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl"" style=""color:#0563c1
column2: text-decoration:underline"">graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.&nbsp
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109092,2022,Sustainable and Equitable Food Strategies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Mugnai'],,"Inhoud

The Sustainable and Equitable Food Stategies (SEFS) course aims at applying a transdisciplinary approach to answer wicked problems in the global food sector, focusing on management studies, and introducing some basic concepts of environmental sciences and social sciences. The ultimate goal is making management studies in the food sector more transformative by tackling both personal and global political aspects. The course offers an overview of the food system by investigating and exploring 3 levels of interaction: Macro (society and environment), Meso (companies) and Micro (individual consumers).

At the end, students will understand the interactions between the actors of the ""global food chain"" (such as governments, international institutions, local market/producers, the big food corporations and supermarket chains) that shape our food system. Sustainability in the food sector will be further analysed from the perspective of the United Nation’s Sustainability Goals.

The course draws on using a problem-oriented project-work approach by implementing action learning techniques, as well personal food journals and business case assessments, with a particular focus on corporate social responsibility and responsible citizenship. Major themes include the sustainable and equitable properties of food, transformations in food industry and global regulations. Particular attention will be dedicated to DIY sustainability of food that will be tackled from different angles, such as international dietary guidelines, the environmental impact of food production (e.g. organic vs industrial food
column3: animal based vs plant-based food) and societal drawbacks (i.e. food security and food waste management). In order to realize this ambition, the course collaborates with Erasmus Food Lab for cooking workshops where all the theoretical knowledge will be put into practice.</body>

column1: • Acquire an in-depth and systematic knowledge on the management of sustainable and equitable food strategies by:
• Identifying the main actors in the food chain, and recalling both their characteristics and interactions
• Analysing the global and local aspects of food sector from a transformative approach
• Developing strategies in order to create a positive impact for a healthy, sustainable and equitable food system.
• Students are able to design and promote sustainable and equitable food projects using different marketing methodologies by:

• Applying a self-inquiry in the form of a food journal and evaluating individual and organizational actions/behaviour against a framework for sustainable and responsible food practices in interaction with food businesses and organizations
• Engaging others in order to promote sustainable and equitable food strategies (i.e. using different social media channels).
• Develop action-based attitudes to lead transformative changes in organizations by:
• Originating a reflexive and creative attitude to transfer self-gathered knowledge and skills to others
• Creating professional collaboration and develop communication skills to promote sustainability within organizations and towards society.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/109087,2022,Sustainable business models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. RJM van Tulder'],,"Inhoud

Corporate leaders from smaller as well as larger companies, as start-ups as well as big corporates, are nowadays searching for new and more innovative value propositions that can be linked to more future looking and crisis resilient business models. Partly the search is for rejuvenating existing business models, but increasingly the business models introduced are a response to a society that is considered non-sustainable. Enter: the search for sustainable business models. In the literature this tendency is also referred to as ‘shared value creation’, ‘social innovation’ or ‘business model innovation’. Many synonyms are introduced for this ambition. Most of them look at societal issues from a business model (micro level: how to organise it) as well as from a societal level (macro level: what positive consequences will we have from the wide-spread introduction of the business model). &nbsp
<li>Business models: Understanding how company’s ‘value propositions’ are created and implemented in the Netherlands and around the world
column2: we will use various versions and elaborations of the business model CANVAS as red threat for the whole course and for structured conversations.

column1: <li>Wicked problems: Looking at new business models and the way they can create value and/or solve ‘ wicked’ &nbsp
column2: societal problems in general and the sustainable development goals in specific

column1: • Context: Considering the extent to which business models can become sustainable in varying contexts: international (the influence of country and regulation), per sector, per issue that companies are confronted with

<li>Critical: Understanding the pros and cons of a variety of new economic models, that are related to new business models: circular economy, the we/shared-economy, the upcoming relevance of (energy) cooperatives
• Understanding what the start-up conditions for new and innovative business models are: such as for instance ‘ social enterprise’ and their challenge to get out of the ‘valley of death’
<li>Incumbents and innovation: Understanding what business model innovation looks like from the perspective of ‘incumbents’ &nbsp
column2: (firms that have already a leading position in a market)

column1: <li>New institutional and organizational forms: studying partnerships as part of sustainable business model innovation around the world
column2: from the perspective of companies, NGOs and governments

column1: <li>Sharing: understanding what the business case for ‘shared value creation’ could look like for firms and value chains
column2: how the micro-level of a firm (input dimension of sustainability) can be linked to the macro-level of society (output/outcome dimension of sustainability)

column1: • Leadership and motivation: what distinguishes a sustainable leader from a non-sustainable leader? If so desired: defining your own leadership potential and checking how leadership is needed for business model innovation (use the leadership profiler)
<li>Support in your Master thesis effort (provided you write a master thesis that is linked to the sustainable business models theme)
column2: this elective will directly support your master thesis ambitions by linking theory to practice (and hopefully also practical applications)

In this session you will learn how to (further) develop the front end of your research paper-in-progress. The four modules of this session will centre around the structure and contents of your abstract, introduction, literature review, and theory development. In short, everything preceding your empirical study will be discussed in depth. Getting your paper's front end right is challenging but surely doable and critical to the success of the entire paper.

Prior to the session you will peruse relevant literature and submit your paper's front end, on which you will get personalized feedback. During the session we will have plenary and break-out discussions on each element of a paper's front end.

Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

Ask any business leader to mention the most important drivers for his/her success and you’ll find that “my ability to hire the best people in my teams” is one of them. With the above in mind these 4 observations are striking: (a) in business schools, there is zero to none academic training in “hiring people”, (b) almost no companies train their managers profoundly on this skill, (c) Tasks around “hiring people”, like job interviews, make up for a large part of a business leader’s day to day agenda, especially in more senior career stages, and (d) the academic state-of-the art knowledge on what is good practice has multiple extreme gaps with what happens in everyday business life. For instance, many organizations still base selection decisions on invalid and unreliable selection methods, thus making a bad-informed hiring decision.&nbsp

In this course we will take two perspectives to which related learning goals are related. First, you as a hiring manager: boosting your ability to make effective hiring decisions yourself. Second, you as a business leader: enhancing your ability to contribute strategically to the talent-acquisition goals of others in an organization.&nbsp

In order to achieve these goals, this course will provide insights in the fundamentals of the talent acquisition process, how to effectively acquire/match talent to business needs and modern-day talent acquisition/recruitment/selection methods. The course engages students through a combination of lectures, practical case studies, debates, exercises and discussions. &nbsp

column4: Understand the fundamentals of talent acquisition, recruitment and selection methods
Explain the interfaces between talent acquisition and other elements of the organization
Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case
Be able to critically evaluate business cases.</body>

Taxes affect many business decisions, such as: where to invest, what organizational form to choose, how to finance a business, when and where to recognize revenues and expenses. This is an introductory course providing you with an overview of what taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and what the fundamentals of domestic and international taxation are.

The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This knowledge is complemented by information about recent political developments in the area of taxation. The content from the lecture is applied and deepened during workshops. Guest lectures provide additional insights from practice.

The fundamentals in domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.</body>
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
<li>Solve tasks that include taxes in financial planning
<li>Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices
<li>Evaluate when business profits and when shareholder level profits are taxed
<li>Evaluate double tax agreements and multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation
• Create recommendations for business decisions including taxes and present them in a report.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105381,2022,Taxation of Multinationals,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. DS Schindler'],,Inhoud

In international taxation, the most prominent and hotly debated issue is how to tax multinational companies. In other words, the debate is about how to handle profit-shifting activities by multinationals, or international corporate tax avoidance in more general. Anecdotic evidence shows that large multinational companies such as Google and Apple, but also IKEA manage to avoid almost all tax payments. Even state-owned companies like the Norwegian Equinor (formerly Statoil) use international tax shelters to reduce their global tax payments.

The issue became a major challenge to public policy. Being concerned about losses in tax revenue and an imbalance in the distribution of the tax burden on individuals and firms, the G20 countries and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) started the still ongoing “Base Erosion and Profit Shifting” (BEPS) project in 2012 that in recent years came up with various proposals to regulate firms’ activities and their scope to shift profits. In its 2013-report, the OECD states that “at stake is the integrity of the corporate income tax”.

On the other hand, corporate income taxes are (one of) the biggest cost blocks in corporations, and it appears natural that firms try to reduce costs and respond to tax incentives. Indeed, (some) profit shifting can reduce the distortions created by taxing mobile capital investment and help to implement a beneficial tax differentiation between mobile and immobile tax bases.

Consequently, both profit shifting and its regulation via anti-avoidance rules come with benefits and costs. To be in a position to evaluate the implications of profit shifting, the need and design of regulation, the impact of tax havens, but also to understand the decision making in multinationals and their structure, it is first necessary to have a good understanding of
• how international tax regulation looks like, and
• how multinationals minimize their global tax payments.

Following up on these issues, the course has three parts, beyond setting the stage in chapters 1 and 2. Part 1 focuses on transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel (chapter 3). Part 2 examines international debt shifting in a tax-efficient capital structure as a tool to save taxes (chapters 4 to 6). Finally, Part 3 discusses the institutional design and the effects of the most important anti-avoidance regulation (thin capitalization rule, controlled-foreign-company rules) in chapter 7 and recent policy proposals on formula apportionment and global minimum taxation in chapter 8.
The structure of the course roughly is as follows:
2. The International Tax System: A Basic Overview
3. Transfer Pricing and International Profit Shifting
4. Capital Structure and Taxation in a Domestic Firm
7. Anti-avoidance Regulation: Thin Capitalization Rules, CFC rules (and CCCTB)
8. Formula Apportionment and Recent Tax Reform Proposals

The aim of this course is to provide students with advanced (expert) knowledge on transfer pricing and debt shifting, and a thorough background in how international (corporate) taxation affects decision making in multinational companies. The course analyzes both strategies to optimize global corporate tax payments in multinational companies and their impact on investment decisions. It aims for embedding institutional details of tax systems and anti-avoidance regulation in theoretical models of behavior and for contrasting the theoretical insights with empirical evidence. The course has three parts. In a smaller part 1, transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel is discussed. A larger part 2 focuses on international debt shifting and adjustments in the firms’ capital structure as a tool to save taxes. Finally, part 3 presents, analyzes, and discusses the two most relevant anti-avoidance rules (thin capitalization and CFC rules). Furthermore, it covers the recent policy debate on fundamentally reforming the tax system towards formula apportionment, and it provides a brief overview on the recent OECD/G20 initiative called Pillar I and II (global minimum tax, sales-based taxation of super-profits in selected multinationals).
• have an advanced understanding of the theory behind how international taxation affects firm behavior, how firms set up a tax-efficient financing structure, and how tax planning affects investment.
• are informed about empirical evidence on both multinationals’ tax avoidance and its regulation.
• know the main regulatory framework and institutional setting to limit international tax avoidance (arm’s length principle, thin capitalization rules, controlled-foreign-company rules).
Upon successful completion of the course, the students
• acquired an analytical tool set that allows for formally structuring and solving tax-avoidance problems, but also for evaluating the welfare impact of tax havens and the design of regulation.
• can outline set-ups for independent empirical studies on profit shifting.
• are able to independently analyze and evaluate the implications of future changes in regulation and the institutional setting.
• can apply their knowledge on international tax avoidance and firms’ behavior in an abstract, but still meaningful way.
Furthermore, more generally, when having taken and successfully passed the course, the students should
• have advanced expertise on international income shifting by transfer prices and debt.
• be able to evaluate pro and cons of profit shifting and its regulation.
• be in a position to communicate with specialists in both academia and practice about complex issues in international tax avoidance and the BEPS debate.

<body>Contemporary culture is out of phase with technical progression, either considering it as a threat or as neutral matter to be exploited by humanity. According to the philosopher of technology Gilbert Simondon, both positions are inadequate. Instead, technology must be understood in its technicity, which is fully relational and involves a reconsideration of classical conceptual dualisms such as form and matter, design and production, work and life, all of which obscure the mode of existence of technical objects. In this intensive three-week workshop students will examine how the form and the function of technical objects have the capacity to transform both humans and environment. The aim is to extract knowledge from the readings and orient them into speculative research statements that will produce a series of material and technological experimentations as a final output. The students work in transdisciplinarily composed groups of max. 5 and are asked to produce a physical model that serves as the materialisation of their speculative research statement. In addition, they should prepare supplementary material to the model, such as drawings or short texts. The students are asked to present their models and other material in the end of the workshop in 20 min. presentations followed by (peer-)feedback. The products will be exhibited online.</body>
Upon completion of the three modules, the students will have:

o Acquired the academic skills for thinking, reading, presenting, and collaborating in an inclusive and transdisciplinary manner, in particular a sensibility for problems at the interface of architecture and philosophy
o Acquired a conceptual toolbox for thinking in terms of relations and speculative-interactive design
o Learned to apply contemporary ideas and debates in a dynamic urban setting in engaged, responsible, and non-reactive ways
column2: Acquired or developed basic (technical) design skills while contributing to ecological literacy.

In this practical, the student becomes familiar with, and learns to use different neuroscientific research techniques that can be used in forensic neuroscience, such as electroencephalography (EEG), (functional) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and transcranial Current Stimulation (tCS). It is important that the student learns that, especially in this target group of forensic patients, neuroscientific research offers starting points for practice (including violence risk assessment and management), and is therefore an evidence-based approach.
In addition, the students will learn to use all this information on neuroscientific research techniques to write a report to the court as expert witness.</body>
During this course, the student learns to:
• Make an informed choice for different neuropsychological or neuroscientific methods to investigate suspects and perpetrators.
• Explain in the role of expert witness on the basis of neuroscientific information why a particular punishment or measure is or is not appropriate for a particular suspect.
