column1: In this course, you learn how digital technologies shape, improve, or deteriorate fundamental human processes, such as attention, memory, and cognition. You learn that consumers make different decisions depending on the device-interface (e.g., touch versus voice interface) utilized and share more information about themselves when using a smartphone (as compared to another device). We will discuss the implications for individuals, society, and companies.</body>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:
• Understand how digital technologies impact cognitive processes and behaviour
• Develop hypotheses about the impact of digital technologies on cognitive processes and behaviour
• Develop experimental paradigms to study the impact of digital technologies on cognitive processes and behaviour
• Learn to consult others (e.g., government or companies) on how individuals make decisions and behave
• Develop intervention strategies involving digital technologies to nudge consumers to make better decisions

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107675,2022,Technology Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CW Hagen', 'KWA van Dongen', 'LMM Gross, MSc', 'M Sovago', 'MJ Iwanczuk-Prost', 'prof.dr. DA Stam', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

For centuries, technology has been one of the most important pillars of the economy. Both in production-oriented sectors and in service companies, technology plays an important role. Without technological progress, companies will lose their competitive advantage. Managers have to face the question of how to make the most of technology. What technology is available and which technological innovations are developing? What might be the consequences of a technology for a company, a particular sector or society? What is the role of technology in the strategy of a company regarding its product/services, the production process and the core competencies? In short, how can managers recognize relevant technologies and properly implement them in a company? In this course, you will develop a technology strategy for one crucial high-end technology embedded in a core product of a case company by combining technological and business criteria.

The course is about the management of a company’s high-end technology that is embedded in one of the company’s core business or consumer products. The technology is an essential part of the product, but it may become outdated because of the rise of alternative technologies. These emerging technologies have the same functionality as the current technology, but may (in the future) add more value to the company’s core products and its customers. Therefore, the new technological developments need to be considered for sustainable competitiveness. It does not focus on the question of how to meet a short-term demand in the market by means of technology (market pull), but the focus will be on how an upcoming technology can be used in the longer run for redesigning products/services, production processes or core competencies of a company (technology push).

It is not evident that a company should always shift to the (technologically better) alternative. Introducing an emerging technology may have serious effects on the product, the production processes, the company at large, and the business environment. Therefore, managers should carefully evaluate and compare existing and emerging technologies and their effects. Therefore, the main question in this course is: should the company shift to an emerging technology, and if so to which one?

The aim of this course is to write a strategic plan for an existing company with high-tech products that could apply an alternative technology in one of its core products. In order to reach that goal, you have to analyse the company’s current situation (Assignment 0), compare the current technology with the emerging ones (Assignment 1), study the effects of emerging technologies on the company and its environment (Assignment 2), and combine this information into a proposal for a technology strategy (Assignment 3), which has to be summarized and presented during an executive presentation (Presentation).

The course can be related to SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Part of assignment 2 and 3 is to consider the (societal) environment while thinking about the implementation of the emerging technologies.
<body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• Manage (ones role in) an interdisciplinary, collaborative group.
• Critically evaluate the impact of a technology on an organisation and its environment
• Communicate a strategic recommendation for a case company regarding their future use of technology
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106288,2022,Technology and Social Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. JD Raven'],,Inhoud

Modern technology evidently shapes our world in a historically unprecedented scale. On the one hand it enables us to control, organize and optimize activities and functions of our everyday lives, on the other hand it leads to the incessant unfolding of an ecological catastrophy and continuously changes the fabric of our society, unceasingly altering its organizational structure, our goals, the ways we interact with each other and our environment(s) and the standards we set for ourselves and each other.

A classical critique in the philosophy of technology is that technology in general creates a distance between us (as individuals), and between human beings and their surrounding world. In this regard, the great developments in technology arguably lead to the illusion that everything around us is controllable, rendering us ‘safe’ at a distance. Other approaches focus instead on the mediating and connecting function of technology, which opens up new ways of experiencing, communicating and even developing into a completely different being. Some of the questions that motivate this course are: does technology really help us to disclose the world and connect with others, or rather does it alienate us from nature, others and ourselves? How is society affected by technology? Are we shaping technology or does technology shape us and our social lives? Who or what is in control? We will see that all these relevant questions concerning modern technology unavoidably centre around and revive philosophical reflections related to our humanity and being human, freedom and determinism.

We will first reflect on and warm up for philosophy of technology as such by comparing introductionary texts of some serious pioneers in the field, with Ellul and Jonas pointing to the inconvenient powers released by modern technology. Then, (week 2) we will read some authors emphasiszing technology as a more contingent, man-made, social construct. However, therafter (week 3) we deal with a recently developed account of the phenomenon of so-called social acceleration, i.e. the fateful speeding up of society, enabling us to look on our technological society as a system with its own dynamics, followed (week 4) by Heidegger’s renowned and profound contribution to the question of technology, with his fundamental ontological reflection on the essence of modern technology. Subsequently we will regard the ontological and existential import of modern media technologies (week 5), enabling us to play and experiment with identities and ways of life, and prepare for reflection on its much discussed, both celebrated

and detested algorithms (week 6). Finally, we discuss the future of (post)human society by studying ethical approaches to artificial intelligence (week 7) and possible directions for human enhancement (week 8).
At the end of the course, students should
a) have acquired basic knowledge of the concepts and debates in the philosophy of technology
• describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes
<li>compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the philosophy of technology and related scientific studies of technology
• reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology
• apply this knowledge to analyze how recent technology and society mutually shape each other.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106509,2022,Technology, Media and Identity",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JH Pridmore', 'FM Bellaard, MA', 'P Mashigo, MA']",,"Inhoud

<body>The integration of new forms of technology and media into everyday life have begun to alter our sense of who we are and what we are about as human beings. Our sense of self – our identity – has shifted as ubiquitous technology and predictive algorithms become part of our social experiences. This is clearly evident in forms of social media, news and entertainment, but digitalisation has also changed the way we work, the way we shop, the way we date and the way we relate to our families. This course begins to explore these themes, starting with a clearer understanding of how social interaction and relationships produce and affect identity and how technology has become a mediating factor in our identity ‘constructions’. This is an incremental change from previous notions of self that were intimately attached to place, name and status or position. By focusing on media and technology, the course is intended to develop students’ critical self-reflective awareness of identity in the contemporary era and how media and technology affect the current and future shaping of self. The course draws on contemporary theories of identity, but also takes a practical approach by examining several domains in which identity is shaped. These domains take into consideration how technology and media are integrated into family and intimate relationships, workplaces, marketing, politics, entertainment, and news, giving grounding for a deeper understanding and awareness of identity in these contexts.</body>
• The nature of identity theory as a field of social scientific study.
• The basic theories, concepts, and notions of identity and the ‘self’.
• The effects and influences of technology and media on identity.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
• Analyse how media and technology intersect with constructions of identity.
• Appraise differing technologies and their influence in communication contexts and domains that are part of people’s personal and professional lives.
• Evaluate and reflect on the ways in which ubiquitous technology and predictive technologies will evolve in the future and the implications for people’s future sense of self.
• Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.
• Reflect on how media and technology is influencing their personal life.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104967,2022,Technology, Policy and Society",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. A Albareda Sanz', 'dr. RFI Moody']",,"Inhoud
<body>Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19<sup>th</sup>&nbsp
column2: and the first half of the 20<sup>th</sup>&nbsp
column3: century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT&nbsp
column4: within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

column1: De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding / For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials
<body>After having followed the course, students are able to
• Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today's information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain how technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Name and reflect on ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106548,2022,Television Audiences,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg'],,"Inhoud

<body>Central in this course are research on television audiences and on audience reception. While many studies focus on the content of media, audience receptions of that content have been under-researched. Consequently, conclusions about media impact often remain rather speculative. In this course, we will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, and religion in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions, while different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in multiple ways.&nbsp
column2: Various forms of qualitative data-collection and data–analysis (e.g. individual interviews, focus groups, construction of topic list) will be discussed in order to prepare students to conduct independent research into television audiences. The assignments give students room to focus on TV genres/formats they are interested in. The various steps in the actual research process will be discussed and related to specific assignments in the course.

column1: <li><span style=""color:#000000"">The interaction between media representations and audience receptions
<li><span style=""color:#000000"">Audience reception research, with a specific focus on popular television genres and social dimensions such as gender, race, ethnicity, religion
• The different components of qualitative audience-related research and how these components relate to each other.
• Conduct qualitative audience research into TV audiences both individually and in teams.
<li><span style=""color:#000000"">Reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field
Apply practical skills required for qualitative audience research, e.g. drafting a topic list, interviewing, qualitative data-analysis, presenting findings.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106501,2022,Television Industries in the Age of Streaming,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. ML Wayne'],,"Inhoud

<body>This is an exciting and transformative moment for television industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, video on-demand services that provide directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. The growth of Disney+’s subscriber base to more than 100 million users in less than eighteen months, for example, demonstrates traditional players’ commitment to streaming distribution. Similarly, the global expansion of streaming platforms like Netflix are simultaneously reflections and drivers of change within the traditional television industries. To address these issues, this course uses a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television industries in the age of streaming.</body>
Students will have gained knowledge and understanding of:
• Theoretical approaches and key concepts related to the analysis of television industries.
• Perspectives on television at the level of industry, audience, and text.
• Analyze and explain television industries in a variety of contemporary contexts.
• Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding television industries.

Dit practicum bouwt voort op de diverse practica waarin studenten kennis en ervaring hebben opgedaan van verschillende aspecten van het meer klinische werk als pedagoog. In dit practicum leer je om diagnostiek uit te voeren en daarbij oog te hebben op verschillende factoren die van invloed kunnen zijn op de ontwikkeling van een kind.

De studenten oefenen met het afnemen van diagnostische instrumenten bij een kind in de basisschoolleeftijd (bij voorkeur zonder ontwikkelingsproblemen). Daarnaast worden de gedragsontwikkeling en de (opvoed)omgeving in kaart gebracht. Als eindopdracht schrijft de student een klinisch onderzoeksverslag met ouders als doelgroep, zodat ze oefenen met het vertalen van onderzoeksresultaten naar leken. Daarnaast wordt er in de bijeenkomsten geoefend met het voeren van gesprekken met ouders over de onderzoeksresultaten. De testafname en/of het oudergesprek wordt geëvalueerd in een zelfreflectieverslag.

In het practicum wordt er duidelijk een connectie gemaakt met de klinische praktijk. De kennis en vaardigheden die in dit practicum worden opgedaan zijn een goede voorbereiding op de praktijkstage in de bachelor of master
Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

<li><span style=""color:#212529"">bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek op een praktijkgerichte manier te beschrijven
<li><span style=""color:#212529"">bevindingen uit het ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek terug te koppelen aan een ouder

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104750,2022,Text mining and Data Visualization in R,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['drs. AB Boot, MSc', 'G Martins Van Jaarsveld']",,"Inhoud

<body>Each week, you will perform an R assignment based on an online video tutorial. The video tutorials will be accessible via Canvas. You will perform the assignments at home on your personal computer (pc or mac). The first tutorial will introduce you to the basic functionalities of RStudio. Each of the three subsequent video tutorials will guide you through a specific aspect of the Twitter research flow. In the second tutorial you will learn how to independently collect a large dataset of Twitter messages (i.e., tweets and complementary information). The third tutorial will show you how to preprocess the data and how to perform a sentiment classification (i.e. how to classify Twitter messages into ‘positive’ and ‘negative’ categories). The final tutorial will guide you to analyze your results and produce descriptive and inferential statistics and figures.</body>

<body>The purpose of this practicum is twofold: you will learn how to use R and you will independently perform a comprehensive research procedure involving the investigation of (text-based) Twitter data.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107891,2022,The Art of Choosing: Making choices that maximize happiness,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. J Boegershausen'],,"Inhoud

Choices ranging from the mundane to the profound are an essential part of our daily life. Given the proliferation of digital technologies and consumptions into all spheres of life, we make more choices than ever before. Just consider how many choices you already made today before you started reading this course manual. At a more fundamental level, being able to decide for ourselves can provide a sense of control and autonomy that is essential to well-being and human flourishing. Yet how to make choices that bring us happiness, provide purpose, and allow us to enhance our quality of life and well-being often remains elusive.

In this minor, we will deconstruct choice and why it matters so much. We will explore whether there ever can be too much choice and the myriad influences that context has on our decisions and choices. At the end of the course, you will be able to leverage these insights to make better choices for the good of yourself and others.

Understanding and overcoming our own biases and shortcomings in choice may not only increase happiness but also can also facilitate being a force for positive change. At a more personal level, the Art of Choosing is designed to help every single course participant reflect on what “the good life,” i.e., a life well-lived, means to you. During the course, we will explore different perspectives ranging from the good life as happy, meaningful, and to the psychologically rich life. In the words of Aristotle, “knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.” Building on that knowledge, this course will equip you with frameworks and tools to craft and curate compelling customer experiences that facilitate better choices for consumers and firms alike.
After following this course, you will be able to:
<li>Understand how choices influence different forms of happiness&nbsp
<li>Identify and analyze relevant situational influences that might shape choice&nbsp
<li>Engage in critical self-reflection about your own decisions&nbsp
<li>Learn how we can make better choices for ourselves and others&nbsp
<li>Evaluate different approaches to curate choice sets and assortments that create value for consumers and firms&nbsp
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103735,2022,The Avant-Garde: Experimental Art, Photography and Film",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

Avant-Garde is the French military term for front-guard and is generally used to describe the most adventurous manifestations of modern art, photography and film. Art – in the broadest sense of the word - that forges ahead, breaks down barriers and challenges the status quo, but at the same time, art that is difficult, sometimes incomprehensible and elitist. Through a combination of the humanities and sociological perspectives, we will trace the roots of the Avant-Garde, examine the challenges that avant-garde artists faced and discuss whether avant-garde art is still possible today.

<span style=""color:black"">The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts (i.e. fine arts, photography, film) and society from – roughly - 1850 to the present. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context

All this will lead up to a symposium that we will organise at the end of the course, during which students will present and discuss short papers about the several themes that we discussed during our lectures and museum visits.

The aim of the course is to create insight into the relationships between the visual arts and society for approximately the last 150 years. Students will become familiar with the most influential visions on avant-garde art, the most influential critiques of avant-garde art, and the most ‘canonical’ examples of avant-garde art. Students will be able to think, write and talk about avant-garde art in its historical and social context
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104737,2022,The Brain,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MI Sahan', 'drs. AB Boot, MSc']",,"Inhoud

The brain: maybe the most important organ of our body. Without the brain we would not be aware of anything around us. The world would not exist for us. It’s not our eyes that make us see, it’s not our ears that make us hear. It is only in our brain were we become aware of what we see and what we hear. In this course you will learn about this exciting organ, the brain, with its neural circuits giving rise to psychological functions like cognition and emotion.

Everything that happens in the brain is the result of interactions between brain cells, the neurons. Neurons communicate with each other through chemical substances. In this block you will learn how this communication takes place and what happens when this communication goes wrong in clinical disorders like depression and schizophrenia. You will also learn how the brain develops, how neural circuits arise and how these are subject to modifications as a result of experience.

Brain research is constantly giving us new ideas about how the brain works and what happens when things seem to go wrong in the brain. There are still many things that we (or better ‘science’) do not exactly know about the brain. This makes it a very exciting topic to study. If everything would be known already, it would be less fun. Actually, some say that we might never be able to understand the brain completely. As L. Watson, a well-known scientist, said: &nbsp
”If the brain were so simple we could understand it, we would be so simple we couldn't.”
Indeed, brain is a comprehensive subject.&nbsp
column2: You will learn a lot of new names and terms and this might be a little confusing in the beginning. When you feel like this, just think of the following quote from another scientist, W. Rogers:&nbsp

column1: “You know you've got to exercise your brain just like your muscles"".</body>
<body>At the end of this course, you will have a deeper understanding of

column9: the cellular basis of brain functioning and neural circuits (including the role and working of neurotransmitters and receptors, and the cascade that the binding of a neurotransmitter to a receptor sets off).
how neural circuits arise in the development of the brain.
how modifications of neural circuits take place as a result of experience and learning
the biological basis of brain dysfunctions (e.g. psychiatric disorders) and the working of psychotropic drugs
the process of recovery after brain damage, involving neuroplasticity

<body>Are you interested to use academic knowledge to solve real-life problems in cities today? Does the prospect of doing engaged research on urban challenges in dialogue with citizens’ groups, policymakers, government officials, and urban practitioners excite you? This practise-oriented course is built around pop-up ‘CityLabs’ in which students and diverse urban stakeholders meet over a period of 2 months to tackle a specific urban problem. This problem could relate to urban economies, resilience in the face of climate change, housing issues, or equitable access to public spaces. Through the CityLabs, you will explore existing ways in which this problem is being handled, search for new perspectives, suggest a tentative solution, test this solution in a practical setting, and then evaluate its efficacy. This course offers hands-on training in what goes into addressing the challenges of urbanization in post-industrial cities.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103757,2022,The Climate Crisis: Ecology, Economy & Politics in the Anthropocene",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['AK Fretz', 'drs. LA Doeland', 'S Boersma, PhD']",,"Inhoud
There is consensus among scientists in fields that are contributing to the study of climate change
that mankind has a negative impact on our climate and that we are rapidly running out of time to
avert a catastrophically changed climate. Still we mankind, as a whole - do not seem to be in a
hurry to change the ways in which we have organised our everyday lives, our economies and our
societies. Why? And what is to be done?
In this course we discuss the ways in which we shape the climate and the climate has shaped, and
will continue to shape, us from the very distant past to the not so distant future. By combining
perspectives from philosophical anthropology, psychology, political economy and (geo)politics
students get a thorough introduction into the problematic of climate change. Throughout the
course we pay particular attention to the concept of the Anthropocene as well as its uses and
abuses in popular discourse and academic disciplines as varied as climate sciences, geology, social
<li>Have a basic understanding of the causes and consequences of Climate Change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the debate about the (use and abuse of the term) Anthropocene
<li>Have a basic understanding of economic solutions to climate change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the politics of climate change
<li>Have a basic understanding of the pros and cons of technological fixes
<li>Have a basic understanding of the SF mode in both its literary and theoretical sense
• Have an advanced understanding of the work of key thinkers on Climate Change such as Latour and Haraway, Moore and Giddens and Morton and Jonas.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106392,2022,The Cultural Economic Perspective,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. T Navarrete Hernandez'],,"Inhoud

<body>The main objective of this course is to familiarize students with key concepts and major perspectives – developments, trends, and problems – in the economics of art and culture. The course will present the cultural economic perspective as developed by David Throsby, Bruno Frey, Arjo Klamer and other economic sociologists and contrast this with the standard economic approach to the arts and culture. The central question is how artists, consumers and cultural organizations realize the social and cultural values of art and culture. Another central theme is how cultural goods are priced and valued in the economy, within society, and within the art world. Special attention will be given to the role of digital technology in the process of valuation and pricing of the arts and culture. During the lectures these issues will be discussed from a theoretical perspective, while the workgroups will focus on the application of these theories to concrete economic phenomena or from the world of arts and culture that are familiar to students from their everyday life.</body>

<body>The goal of this course is to familiarize students with what has come to be called the cultural economic perspective. After this course students should be able to identify the differences between this perspective and the standard economic perspective, and they are expected to be able to analyze various phenomena using the cultural economic perspective.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107992,2022,The High Enlightenment I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

By 1750s the French Enlightenment in particular takes off its gloves. Diderot and D’Holbach start propagating a ‘Spinozist’ materialism, which raises the issue of the origins of the Radical Enlightenment. Simultaneously Rousseau singlehandedly revolutionizes French political thought. Meanwhile, the German Enlightenment (Thomasius, Wolff, Lessing) gets under way and the eighteenth-century culture of sensibility spreads throughout Europe. Following the French Revolution, Burke and De Maistre launch their Counter-Enlightenment, the echoes of which can still be traced in twentieth-century critical accounts of the Enlightenment such as Adorno and Horkheimer’s Dialectics of Enlightenment.
To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by D’Holbach and the so-called ‘radical Enlightenment’. They will understand the main characteristics of Rousseau’s thought. They will be able to distinguish some of the key differences between the French and the German Enlightenment. They will know some of the most important critical assessments of the Enlightenment, put forward during the late eighteenth and the twentieth centuries.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107993,2022,The High Enlightenment II: Kant,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['D Rusu'],,Inhoud

<body>David Hume’s criticism of the notion of causality prompted Immanuel Kant to develop a new philosophy in which causality is no longer a property of the world outside us, but rather a concept in our minds that assists us in making sense of the world. This is his famous ‘Copernican Revolution’
column2: rather than objects in the world shaping the cognitive operations of subjects (epistemological realism), these subjective operations determine our perceptions of objects and our judgements about objects (epistemological idealism). This is only part of Kant’s enormous contribution to philosophy. In his ethics he defended morality in the form of a law that demands to be obeyed for its own sake, the commands of which are not issued by some alien authority but the voice of reason that the moral subject can recognize as his own.

column1: Finally, although Kant was a great Enlightened demolisher of the truth of metaphysics, he nevertheless maintained that certain notions can still have a useful regulative function
column2: one example is the notion of teleology. This notion plays a major role in his philosophy of history, his political philosophy and his radical plea for world peace, Perpetual Peace (1795)
column3: paradoxically enough, this teleological perspective also implies a surprisingly positive evaluation of the function of war.

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.
A basic understanding of Kant’s metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, philosophy of war and peace, and his philosophy of history.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107749,2022,The International System,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. Y van Hoef']",,"Inhoud

This module provides an introduction to the development of the international political system from 1500 to the present. The focus is on the highest, systemic level: the practice of international politics, its main actors, the rules, assumptions, understandings and norms that underpinned said practice, and how all of these changed over time. Particular attention will be paid to key moments in international history, such as peace conferences, global encounters, major wars and international institution-building, from the encounters of separate civilisations in the 1500s to today’s global governance.

column8: <!--[endif]-->Students will be able to analyse the evolution of the international system since 1500
<!--[endif]-->Students will be able to evaluate theoretical perspectives on the role of ideas versus power in shaping international order since 1500
Students will be able to originate a response paper critically assessing current claims about the future of the international system in the twenty-first century.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107959,2022,The Invention of Pollution: A Playful Investigation,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. YH Hendlin'],,Inhoud
This course is part of the 'Environment, Life and Technology' cluster (cluster 2).

Is pollution just matter out of place? Or is there also thought pollution? Are advertisements matter out of place for some – jarring intrusions into our everyday lives – while being precisely placed by marketers? So, is marketing the discipline of creating pollution? Has psychology been hijacked to make people more neurotic? Has philosophy been spun to create more sophistry? Is there any thing, form, or substance that is incorruptible? If we wish for things to be uncorrupted, why are we in search for it externally? Why are we looking to others for solutions that require changing human character and society?

No other creature in existence produces artifacts that cannot usefully be broken down by other biological organisms. Nor do they concentrate toxins in given areas, or sequester them, festering away, creating dysbiosis. Biological input and output for organisms, then becomes an ecological cycle, where the detritus/effluent/scraps/excrement of one species becomes the food for another in an everflowing chain of composting.

But not industrial culture. While there have been those who bit off the hand that fed them, like the Rapa Nui of Easter Island, such cultures were constrained, geographically, energetically, and ecologically. But industrial culture, with its goals of sustaining unsustainable ways of concentrating power, and then finding ways of fighting back and circumventing ecological, social, psychological, and physiological limits, aims to establish and maintain a status quo of control, no matter the fallout. The collateral damage of this way of separating the self from the environment, undermines the fertility of that which enables the opportunities that begat that/those being(s).

Questions discussed include: When did pollution first begin? What form did it take? Why did it come to pass? What is the link between pollution and instrumentalism? How did pollution become globalized? How was pollution mobilized for colonization? What is pollution’s ‘endgame’? Would you be willing to live without pollution if we all did? Does giving up pollution mean giving up all technology, or might there be some other way to enjoy the fruits of technology without polluting?
Students must attend all seminars except in emergencies communicated before the missed course session in question. Students missing more than 2 seminar sessions are dropped from the class.
• Learn about the history of pollution from several different philosophical perspectives.
• Examine philosophical anthropology applied to a specific case study.
• Analyze different arguments for what constitutes pollution, why it is (un)necessary, and what it reflects.
• Compare competing narratives of pollution and its purposes (the performativity of pollution.

• Synthesize perspectives to form your own original argument, and defend it with argumentation and logic against counterarguments (or modify your original claim in light of convincing counterarguments).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107277,2022,The Origins of Global Order,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. ME Hay', 'dr. S Bertrand']",,"Inhoud

History has seen many types of global orders, from multiple co-existing isolated systems to global unipolar hegemony. This course explores the evolution of the origins of global order from ca. 1500 to the Vienna Settlement of 1815.

On the one hand it seeks to explain how and why certain powers emerged to dominance to define the global order, what strategies and mechanisms they developed that allowed them to order global relations, and how these powers justified their dominance of the global order. On the other hand, this course examines the plethora of challenges to global order, from revisionist powers seeking to develop alternative orders to normative challenges from within the global order.

Through viewing the evolution of global order from a global history perspective, this course aims to challenge some of the established Eurocentric perspectives on the origins and early history of global order.
<li><span style=""background-color:#ffffff"">Drawing on History and International Relations Theory, students can conceptualise global order and related concepts
<li><span style=""background-color:#ffffff"">Students can analyse how order was constructed, deconstructed and reconstructed across the globe, 1500-1815
• Students can discern various scholarly views on the rise and decline of international primacy and how this affects the global order.
• Through learning journal assignments, students can navigate, criticise, and defend scholarly opinions to develop their own substantiated views on key episodes of the history of global order.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105710,2022,The Political Economy of European Integration,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. A Quintavalla', 'JHM Smeets', 'mr. KP Prifti', 'prof.dr. K Heine', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber']",,"Inhoud

'The strongest feature of the course is the combination of Economics, Law, and Politics comprehensively altogether. Students who aspire to specialize in Political Economy, International Trade and Public Policy, or simply wish to broaden their knowledge about the EU should definitely do this Minor’

‘I would recommend this course to anyone who wishes to learn more about the history, workings and mechanisms of the EU. Moreover, the course is structured, the essay allows one to choose a subject and dig deeper into it and the trip to Brussels has been the highlight of the course!’
Pauline van der Vaeren – Rotterdam School of Management

The effects of European Integration can be felt everywhere. At the supermarket you can buy food from other EU countries and the Bologna process led to a harmonization of academic degrees, making it easier for students to study at different universities in the EU. The Erasmus programme allows many students to go abroad and explore both cultural and educational differences. Furthermore, recent events such as Brexit and COVID-19 pandemic have highlighted the political relevance of European Integration.

This course examines practical and theoretical issues concerning European Integration and touches upon economic and legal implications of the European Union: What is the political background of European Integration? How does it affect us in daily life? Is it possible to preserve a country’s specificities, like culture or social security, while at the same time benefitting from more economic exchange?
• Different lecturers giving insights in their specific field of expertise
• A possible trip to Brussels to visit the EU institutions and meet EU decision makers
<body>After following this course, students will be able to:

<li>Analyse the methodological and theoretical backgrounds of economic theories (such as economic integration, international trade and federalism) by using economics terminology and making use of graphs
<li>Summarise the foundations and basic principles of the European legal system by using legal terminology
• Critically assess a European policy area from a legal and economic perspective involving the insights of economic theories and legal rules in their argument.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106397,2022,The Popular Music Hit Song Project,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JCF Schaap', 'W Coppes, MA']",,"Inhoud

<body>In this hands-on project-course, students will work together with Codarts students to fabricate a ‘hit’ song. This course aims to have students submerged in the ‘real-life’ practice of popular music production and distribution. This does not only involve the making of the music itself (including recording and production), but especially the social and industry practices discussed in the other courses of the minor programme. This means that students will set a goal for their hit (e.g. mainstream or underground scene) and work on getting the song ‘out there’ through the right channels, (social) media and – hopefully – (online) stages. These projects are presented in a final symposium at the end of the minor. Students will have weekly project meetings at Codarts (Rotterdam-West), supported by multiple coaches from the field of contemporary music production. Rehearsal spaces and studio time will be made available by Codarts. Students are expected to show a high level of independence and academic maturity to bring this course to completion.</body>

This course is exclusively for students enrolled in the minor ‘MU$IC: The economy, sociology, and practice of popular music’. In this project-course, students will work together with Codarts students to fabricate a ‘hit’ song. After following this course, students can creatively apply their knowledge on the sociology and economy of music in musical entrepreneurship, will have an in-depth understanding of the production and distribution of contemporary ‘hit’ songs and can apply this in practice.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105227,2022,The Practice of Financial Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. DL Urban'],,Inhoud

This course presents a concise overview of financial markets. This includes coverage of a wide array of financial assets, the risks associated with their use, various trading mechanisms employed by exchanges and different forms of organization that govern the interaction among market participants. This will provide students with a solid foundation for understanding the continually evolving financial system, its institutions, its markets, and its products.

We start with an overview of the financial system and talk about the functions of financial markets and institutions. We describe the financial institutions industry and pay special attention to the mutual fund industry. We cover the basic features of (1) the money markets (2) the bond market (3) the stock market (4) the mortgage markets (5) the foreign exchange market and (6) cryptocurrencies. We touch upon valuation of different financial assets, risk assessment, behavior of the financial asset users and implications of the financial market on the economy as a whole.
• Understand the fundamental concepts of financial markets and market participants.
• Identify and analyze features of financial products developed in various financial markets.
• Apply theories to explain and predict changes in valuation of various financial products.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106423,2022,The Public Role of Historians,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'drs. AG van Ham']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course teaches students how they can use their academic skills and historical knowledge to engage with wider publics. Historians have specific skills which enables them to contribute to public debates or which are useful in professional contexts. The course prepares students for the challenges they will encounter when working as historians in various professional environments, including the museum sector, journalism and radio/television.</body>

<body>The course 'The Public Role of Historians' has the following main objectives. Firstly, students are able to communicate scientific historical knowledge to a broad public. They are able to do so in a number of specific settings, including the museum sector, journalism and radio/television. Secondly, students are able to evaluate different forms of public history. Thirdly, students are able to critically reflect on tensions between professional standards and requirements for public engagement. Fourthly, students are able to carry out a survey study to understand how wider publics engage with history.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107628,2022,The Rise and Fall of the American Empire,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. Y van Hoef']",,"Inhoud

The Research Workshop extends across terms 2 to 4, preparing the students for writing their master’s thesis and guiding the writing process. This workshop comprises all phases, from writing the thesis to presenting the final result. Students choose their own research subjects within the broad overall theme of the Research Workshop. A thesis market is organized before the start of term 2, then students select one of the Research Workshops and research themes on offer. Every Research Workshop is structured in the same way:

column2: discussion of literature as an introduction to the theme
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
critical discussion of the research proposals
discussion of and information on possible research methods
discussion of case studies and other work in progress
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
discussion of case studies and other work in progress
one-on-one progress meetings with thesis supervisor
presentation of the thesis research at master conference in June 2018

column1: The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4.
Theme: The US in a Changing World Order

The rise of the United States as a global power has been one of the defining features of the twentieth century. Throughout the decades, the US has molded the international system in the attempt to create one in its own likeness. This seminar will help the students to reckon with the complex history of US’s positioning in the contemporary world and its varied entanglements in world affairs.

Chronologically, the seminar will mostly focus on the twentieth century. Thematically, it will delve deeper into the various political, cultural, social, and economic dynamics that have shaped both the American foreign policy making process and its outcomes. The seminar will therefore touch on such crucial themes as exceptionalism, empire, Wilsonianism, multilateral diplomacy, world order, hegemony, resistance, and predominance of power. Eventually, the seminar will also sketch out the most important challenges that the US – due its crystallized global leadership – faces in our current days.

By adopting a historical perspective, thus by letting students explore the linchpins of the historiographical debate on US foreign policy and by simultaneously inviting them to critically engage with relevant primary sources, the seminar will provide a broad overview of the US role in the world during the twentieth century (and beyond), and it will stress the transnational nature of the American nation and the structural interdependence it contributed to establishing on a global scale.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October
• Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106834,2022,The Rule of Law in the Global Legal Context,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr. M Stambulski', 'dr. SF Airey', 'prof.mr.dr. HS Taekema']",,"Inhoud

Should businesses be responsible for human rights protection? Does the European Union need to protect judicial independence in Member States? Is the rule of law a concern of states or also of international or even non-governmental organizations? This course discusses such questions against the background of three developments that challenge the functioning of today’s rule of law institutions.

First: the plurality of legal norms in the national, European and inter- and transnational legal context. This multilevel or multidimensional legal order leads to increased complexity, complicated hierarchies, and maybe – depending on the point of view – diminished efficacy when it comes to securing constraints on powerful institutions. Second: the increase in numbers of non-legal actors who are involved in producing official law, but also ‘soft law’ or ‘informal norms’. We may think of NGO’s with ideological interests, lobbyists and large companies with economic interests, and local groups and clans in developing countries. Even if they lack democratic legitimacy, their involvement in the rule making process may be indispensable. Third: the rise of populist democracy and the way the idea of ‘the people’ is contrasted with rule of law institutions. All three of these developments, the transnational increase of legal norms, the variety of actors, and the rise of populism, call into question what the rule of law means today and how it may continue to function.

In this course we will analyse and critically reflect on these developments with the help of theoretical concepts and insights from legal scholarship, legal and political theory, and socio-legal studies. We will illustrate concepts and developments with several cases and social problems debated in today’s legal world.

<body>The overall aim of this course is to give students a contextual understanding of the core legal idea of the rule of law by discussing it against a theoretical and socio-legal background. More particularly, the course aims are that students are able to:&nbsp
• Distinguish various concepts of the rule of law, and their theoretical, political and empirical implications
• Analyse and relate legal, theoretical and empirical problems of the rule of law in situations of multilevel legal orders and global legal pluralism
• Analyse and debate how fulfilment of the ideals of the rule of law is challenged by fundamental value differences and private power holders
• Apply their knowledge and insights creatively to contemporary social and legal problems beyond the state
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104655,2022,The Social Bases of Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. W de Koster'],,Inhoud

column2: Society specialisation familiarises students with the sociological study of politics, focusing on social patterns in public attitudes and political behaviour. How can we understand social differences in support for various value orientations, ideologies, and political parties? And how can we explain social inequalities in political trust and political involvement, both in the formal political domain and in non-institutional politics? There has been a marked decline in Western societies from the 1960s onwards in encompassing political ideologies and the political salience of classic group identities such as classes and religions – a process often referred to as individualisation. This does, however, not imply that value conflicts, voting behaviour, and participation in social movements are no longer socially shaped. On the contrary: old social fault lines have given way to new ones. Systematically combining theories from both sociology and political science with findings from empirical research, this course addresses the contemporary political relevance of these social cleavages. What are their present-day implications? Which groups currently clash over which issues, why is this the case, and how is this related to support for political parties? How can we interpret social differences in anti-immigrant sentiments, political trust, voter turnout, and political protest? And how are these political attitudes and behaviours influenced by online and offline social networks?

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
<li>Discuss the political salience of old and new social divisions and cleavages
<li>Formulate and explain social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours
<li>Analyse social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours and apply these to contemporary social phenomena
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on social differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108724,2022,The Strength of the Wolf is the Pack: Ecosystem Thinking in Strategic Management & Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['A Kantilal Tater, MSc', 'BHE Crombag, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Ecosystem thinking is quickly gaining prevalence in entrepreneurial practice and scholarship. One example of the increasing attention that the ecosystem has been receiving, is the fact that the term was used 160 times in the prospectus of the largest IPO to date. Similarly, a scan of the descriptions of top strategy studies shows that the use of the word had increased sevenfold over a period of five years. Moreover, practitioners and scholars alike have found ecosystem thinking to have real-world value and important implications for organizational outcomes. However, as with many relatively new concepts, what ecosystems are and how they can be ideally orchestrated has remained somewhat hard to grasp and, as a result, is often misunderstood. In this course, we will examine why students (being the strategists and entrepreneurs of the future) need to apply ecosystem thinking. More so, this course aims to give students the tools to do so successfully, providing them with a relevant edge in their prospective careers (whether managerial, entrepreneurial, or academic). This course is designed to provide students a well-rounded/immersive learning experience. To facilitate this, students will have the opportunity to listen to and interact with a wide range of guest speakers, including leaders from a well-known multinational, the Dutch government, as well as a high-tech accelerator. These engagements will enable students to understand how ecosystem thinking is applied and utilised beyond the realm of academia.</body>
At the end of this course students should be able to:
- Effectively employ ecosystem thinking in their (future) career (whether managerial, entrepreneurial, or academic).
- Understand why ecosystem thinking is relevant, valuable and necessary.
- Understand how the success of a value proposition depends on (inter-) dependencies.
- Have a holistic (rather than singular) understanding of what ecosystems are, are not and can be.
- Be able to distinguish between different types of ecosystems and understand how and why these differ.
- Be able to convey the “why” of ecosystem thinking to others.
- Be able to convey the “how” of ecosystem thinking to others.
- Understand several “real life” ecosystems (for instance through the multiple guest speakers).
- Have an overview and understanding of the latest academic developments on ecosystems and ecosystem thinking.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107948,2022,Theatre of the Human,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. GH van Oenen'],,Inhoud

We ask how the sciences of man and of the social perceive what is human and how it is situated in the world. Man and world are not universal, static givens but particular, dynamics products of a multitude of forces and institutions that we usually classify as e.g. economic, social, political, cultural, psychological, historical, architectural, ecological. These perspectives are each tied up with (modern) sciences that propose and legitimate conceptions of both the human and the world. Philosophical anthropology both competes with these perspectives, and aims to bring them together, in a continuing attempt to understand how the human relates to the world and how this is expressed in human self-understanding.

In this course, we will investigate this relation as a ‘theatre of the human’: the human is something performed, performing, and performative, acting within, and out of, the conditions and affordances of the world as he (mis)understands, appropriates, incorporates, and abnegates them. The sciences of man and of the social, to be sure, do not just study, describe, and explain this theatre
column2: they are performative as well, in their representation of the theatrical structure and their rendering of the human and the world. The sciences, in other words, are themselves part of the theatre of the human.

column1: - grasping, and be able to productively work with, differences and similarities in the understanding of the human in philosophy, and in the social and cultural sciences
- understanding the theatrical dimension of the human
- ability to apply basic concepts of philosophical humanities to societal issues</body>
