Dit vak vormt de brug tussen de voornamelijk beschrijvende statistiek (in FEB11005 - Toegepaste Statistiek 1) en het doen van zelfstandig wetenschappelijk onderzoek (bij FEB12012 Methoden en Technieken, FEB12013 Onderzoeksproject, bij de werkcolleges, in de Master programma's, bij de scriptie, en later in de werkpraktijk).

Het vak behandelt statistische methoden en modellen die vaak worden toegepast in de economie, waarbij de juiste aanpak afhangt van de vraagstelling en van de aard van het beschikbare cijfermateriaal. De voornaamste onderwerpen zijn de volgende: toetsen, kruistabellen, ANOVA, niet-parametrische toetsen, regressie (enkelvoudig en meervoudig, tijdreeksen).
Bij de practica worden opdrachten gemaakt en besproken, waarbij practicumpunten vallen te verdienen. Studenten passen verder statistiek zelf actief toe met software.
• De student leert de basisprincipes (beschrijven, schatten en toetsen) en de praktische toepassing van statistiek in de (algemene en bedrijfs-) economie.
• De student maakt kennis met het gebruik van statistische gegevens en modellen voor het wetenschappelijk toetsen van gezichtspunten en het verantwoord onderbouwen van beslissingen.
• De student leert statistische modellen en methoden actief toe te passen met behulp van het statistische pakket SPSS.
• De student wordt voorbereid op zelfstandig statistisch onderzoek in situaties waar de student zelf de onderzoeksvragen formuleert en zelf een model opstelt.

- This course requires the use of the SPSS software (accessible SPSS using the computers in the PC rooms on campus). Students can install it on their personal computer by purchasing it from Surfspot (https://www.surfspot.nl) at a reduced price of €10 the first year + €2.75 every year's renewal.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105066,2022,Toegepaste micro-economie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. J Delfgaauw', 'prof.dr. AJ Dur']",,"Inhoud
Het vak bestaat uit twee onderdelen: personeelseconomie en publieke economie.

• Het eerste deel van het vak bestudeert prikkels voor en motivatie van werknemers in organisaties. De rol van monetaire en niet-monetaire prikkels in het motiveren, selecteren en aantrekken van werknemers staat centraal. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn: de effecten van prestatiebeloning op de motivatie en selectie van werknemers, optimaal aanname- en doorstroombeleid, onderwijs, werken in teams, promotie-toernooien, pensioenen en andere secundaire arbeidsvoorwaarden.

• Het tweede deel van het vak richt zich op het functioneren van markten in het geval van publieke goederen, externaliteiten, en asymmetrische informatie, en de rol van de overheid in het verminderen van de inefficiëntie die ontstaat wanneer markten niet perfect functioneren. Ook verdelingsvraagstukken komen hierbij aan bod, evenals de beperkingen van overheidsinterventies. Tenslotte wordt de normatieve discussie van overheidsinterventie aangevuld met een positieve analyse van collectieve besluitvorming.
• Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden met betrekking tot het werven, selecteren en motiveren van werknemers in organisaties.
• Begrijpen hoe economische theorie gebruikt kan worden voor het bestuderen van het functioneren van markten bij markfalen en de gevolgen van overheidsingrijpen voor efficiëntie en verdeling.

• Het toepassen van concepten en technieken die geleerd zijn bij de eerstejaarsvakken Micro-economie en Wiskunde 1 en 2 voor het analyseren van de effecten van voorgestelde reacties op problemen die besluitnemers tegen komen in de collectieve sector in het bijzonder en in organisaties in het algemeen.

<body>In het vak Toga in Theorie en Praktijk staat een aantal thema’s centraal die als zodanig enerzijds voor de rechtspraktijk van groot belang zijn, en die zich anderzijds lenen voor academische bestudering, in het bijzonder vanuit het voor dit vak gekozen perspectief van de interne rechtsvergelijking tussen de drie hoofdgebieden van het Nederlandse recht. In dit vak zal in het bijzonder aandacht worden besteed aan de rol van partijen, bewijs, spoedprocedures, schadevergoeding, handhaving en alternatieven voor de klassieke procedure. In hoeverre onderscheiden de verschillende rechtsgebieden – na bestudering van de verschillende thema’s – zich van elkaar? Wie kan van wie wat leren? Of is het – vanwege de eigenheid van elk rechtsgebied – niet mogelijk om “best practices” uit te wisselen? Op dergelijke vragen zullen we samen met de studenten antwoord geven.</body>

In dit vak worden de theoretische uitgangspunten van bewijs en waarheidsvinding bezien vanuit de verschillende rechtsgebieden. De student moet de verschillende bewijsstelsels in het bestuurs-, straf- en civiele recht kunnen beschrijven en vergelijken.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106729,2022,Togadragers in de Rechtsstaat,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. C Hofman', 'mr. EJM Roosendaal', 'mr. MR Remmerswaal']",,"Inhoud

Rechters, advocaten en officieren brengen in hun verschillende functies het recht tot leven en geven het zijn maatschappelijke duiding en betekenis. Togadragers bekleden met andere woorden een verantwoordelijke rol in de democratische rechtstaat. Dit vak gaat over de democratische rechtstaat, wat wordt daaronder verstaan en welke regels en kernwaarden staan in deze staatsvorm centraal. Vervolgens gaat dit vak over de (invulling van de) rol door togadragers die in een democratische rechtsstaat functioneren en over de kernwaarden en de beroepsethiek van deze juridische professionals en de organisaties waarbinnen zij hun werk verrichten. Ook wordt in dit vak, mede vanuit rechtsstatelijk perspectief ingegaan op de betekenis voor togadragers en rechtszoekenden van het grondrecht op toegang tot het recht.

<body>Besef van de maatschappelijke context (inclusief het staatsbestel) waarin de togadrager functioneert en creëren van inzicht in de gevolgen hiervan voor de manier waarop aan de rol invulling kan/wordt/zou moeten worden gegeven.&nbsp

In this course we will focus on nonparametric and semiparametric statistical analysis.

We are familiar with methods such as maximum likelihood or linear regression. These are called parametric analysis as the data are assumed to come from a certain distribution (e.g., normal distribution) or have a certain relationship (e.g., linear relationship).
Nonparametric analysis intends to uncover patterns in data without such assumptions. These methods are much more flexible and robust, but also come at a different cost.

Semiparametric analysis intends to reconcile parametric analysis (fast, easy to interpret but restrained by assumptions) and nonparametric analysis (flexible, robust but computationally expensive and not easy to interpret).

We will also talk about bootstrap related methods, which uses randomisation techniques to extract more information about a statistical estimators, thus providing means for estimating biases, standard errors, confidence intervals and conducting hypothesis testing.
The assessment will be based on two programming assignments and a final exam.
• Understand intuition behind bootstrap, nonparametric and semiparametric methods.
• Apply basic bootstrap, nonparametric and semiparametric methods through own programming and advanced methods by existing packages.
• Identify appropriate methods to apply in different data scenarios.

column1: The course’s aim is for students to become proficient in the process of development and execution of research ideas within the fields of Industrial Organization and Organizational Economics. Both fields are large. Rather than a broad overview, this course will discuss several topics in detail. This discussion will be representative for both the type of research questions that are addressed in these fields as well as for the methods of study (theoretical, empirical, and experimental). In class, the lecturers will discuss some of their own papers together with closely related papers. The emphasis will be on how the lecturers developed the research ideas leading to the papers. This means that the lecturers will focus less on the technical details, and more on the creative process.

To stimulate students to take part in the creative process, a substantial part of each lecture will be devoted to discuss the students’ ideas for future research based on the papers discussed. For each lecture, students have to formulate an idea for a research project. Their ideas are discussed during the lecture. To facilitate the discussion, students have to send in a written version (about half a page) of the idea on the day before the lecture. Each idea will be discussed during the lecture
column2: active participation of the other students is expected here.

<body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:
• How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>
• Introduce key concepts and problems in the philosophy of science.
• Develop the capacity of students to critically evaluate concepts and approaches in management science with regards to fundamental problems in the philosophy of science.

<body>Businesses need to purchase goods and services, and those purchases need to be paid. In an international context, effecting a payment is not always straightforward. Therefore, this course looks at (international) payment mechanisms between the parties, including electronic fund transfers (EFT) and electronic currencies, at payment mechanisms involving third parties, such as bills of exchange, documentary collection, documentary credit, etc.&nbsp
column2: Also, companies may need financing, and thus banks, to be able to pay their purchases and working costs (like employees, energy contracts, etc.). In this course credit agreements like (subordinated) loans, overdraft facilities, revolving credit, credit lines, project &amp
column3: real estate financing, etc. will be discussed. Furthermore, we explore the rules and (ISDA)contracts on derivatives

column1: The idea to obtain funds without collateral for the bank is a blissful thought. Hence, the course analyzes and evaluated security mechanisms such as liens and pledges, mortgages, bank guarantees, standby letters of credit, etc.</body>
At the end of this course, the students will:

column5: understand the concepts of money (including virtual currencies) and payment
have a working knowledge of payment services, payment instruments, electronic currencies and electronic funds transfers (EFT), clearing &amp
be aware of and be able to work with the contractual tools that parties can use to structure and limit monetary and payment risks
have an in-depth knowledge of documentary payment mechanisms (CAD, Letters of Credit) and be able to apply that knowledge to solve cases
have a working knowledge of Bank Payment Obligations (BPO)
be able to evaluate and work with different commercial credit agreements and facilities, including export credit, factoring and forfaiting
have an in-depth knowledge of security mechanisms (Standby Letters of Credit, (bank) guarantees and performance bonds) and be able to apply that knowledge to solve cases
have a working knowledge of export credit facilities and credit insurance
be aware of and be able to work with the contractual tools that parties can use to protect their position
have an in-depth knowledge of financial markets, financial instruments &amp

As the world becomes more globalized, and societies become more culturally diverse, it is essential for individuals to develop the skills to communicate effectively with others in intercultural environments. As such, Intercultural communication competences are useful for working in modern organizations in all sectors, including business, public administration, creative industries, education, and health.
This teaching module will be delivered by trainers from Risbo. T

<div>The goal of this module is to provide a basic training in intercultural communication, that is relevant to all students. After completing the module, students are able to:

This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Striving for self-improvement and self-transgression has always been an essential element of the human condition – from the myth of Prometheus, the Renaissance view on man as “the proud shaper of [his] own being” (Pico della Mirandola), to Nietzsche’s vision of the “Übermensch”. Today, important proponents of transhumanism are leading in different fields of the academic discourse, from the researchers of the “Future of Humanity Institute” at Oxford University, to prominent members of the tech elite such as Ray Kurzweil, Google’s director of engineering, or Elon Musk (Tesla, SpaceX). They propagate strong ideals of becoming “super-humans” and claim that the deficient human being ought to be transformed through technological and biomedical optimisation. Many transhumanists emphasize that they develop a new humanist philosophy, rooted in Enlightenment humanism and other historical sources. Most of them consider themselves members of a progressive movement with idealist goals, some have an explicit political agenda. Critiques argue that they foster an inhumane ideology, promoting ideals of the transhuman being as an output oriented, efficiently working high-performer. One could also say that a hetero white patriarchal is their model for human enhancement. However, some transhumanists are open for a “cyberpunk difference model” that is based on the ideal of unfolding human diversity through technology. Though some transhumanists regard human enhancement as a potential solution to the climate crisis another point of critique is directed against their anthropocentrism, promoting an unchallenged, dominating role of the human being as the master of nature.
This course will offer a critical, yet unbiased and philosophically sound discussion of transhumanist views and ideals.

- You will be able to distinguish between different conceptions and ideals of transhuman or superhuman beings, to put these conceptions into a broader historical context of human self-understanding, and to critically discuss different ideals of being human or of transgressing the concept of humanity in view of future prospects and challenges.

- You will be enabled to critically discuss normative and ideological implications of different transhumanist views and ideals and to articulate your own philosophical position with respect to ideals of being (trans-)human.
- You will develop, carry out and assess the results of a collective thought experiment on the creation of superhuman beings – the “Perfect Human Enhancement Laboratory”.

Transmedia Entertainment and Marketing represents a process where different media-platforms are combined to disperse unique content and produce a story (for a media product or consumer brand), allowing for a unified and coordinated entertainment experience, active audience engagement and eventually building a media franchise. What this means is that a story introduced in a film is expanded through television, novels, and comics
column2: its world is explored through game play or experienced as an amusement park attraction and so forth.

column1: Transmedia is also 360 degrees marketing and public relations
column2: allowing companies to produce content on multiple platforms, reach targeted consumers from different angles and most importantly, enabling audiences to actively collaborate, engage and interact with the content itself.

column1: For students who are interested in subjects such as (corporate) communication(s), (communication, business and change) management, business development, marketing, public relations, branding, journalism, storytelling, entrepreneurship and the creative / cultural industries in general, the course presents valuable and indispensable insights in relation to current studies and latter professional activities.
In this course, we will follow the life cycle of two types of content: media texts and consumer brands by examining (marketing) texts and visual content
column5: franchises, world building as well as branded entertainment strategies.

column1: We will also critically examine the challenges and opportunities of this quite recently acknowledged trend of Transmedia storytelling in relation to marketing, branding and (the influence of) audience/ consumer networks. <body>In this practical course, students will have an opportunity to learn directly from experienced forensic therapists. Each week, students will be presented with therapy options that received the most empirical support for specific diagnoses covered in the main part of the course. At the end of the practical course, students will be familiar with five different approaches to treatment, and will be equipt to understand the mechanisms behind all of them. By providing a wide spectrum of treatment options, students will also be equipped to make more informed decisions about their future education in psychotherapy.</body>
Gain insight in the three most common treatment approaches for different disorders (Schema therapy, EMDR, CBT).
Gain insight in the scientific background of treatment interventions.
Critically examine the utility and value of treatment interventions in certain forensic populations.</body>

The world of Data Science is buzzing with exciting innovations and daunting insights. In this extracurricular course, we will focus on understanding the underlying data generating process (DGP). As opposed to solely focusing on Deep Neural Networks, we will go through the process of Data Exploration and Transformation as well. After understanding the dataset at hand, we will introduce a diverse set of possible models. Students will select one group of models to apply to their dataset depending on the aim of the project.
• Students are able to program the fundamental algorithms/models for Machine &

The course describes and offers hands-on practice with the UCSC Genome Browser, the premiere tool for visualization of genomic data. It will teach navigation in the Browser, loading of user data as custom tracks and how to save and share stable links to sessions for future use. It is also useful in interpreting variants in the context of what may already be known about them (benign, pathogenic). Session images can be exported for publication.&nbsp
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.
<li>Explore the genomic databases at the University of California Santa Cruz.&nbsp
<li>Load user data (including patient variants if available) into the Browser for visualization.&nbsp
<li>Save and share sessions for future use, including publications.&nbsp
<li>Use the Genome Browser to interpret variants both large and small.&nbsp
*the program may be subject to change.
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.&nbsp
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.&nbsp

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.&nbsp
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the <a href=""mailto:graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl"" style=""color:#0563c1
column2: text-decoration:underline"">graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

Many of the implications of today’s personalization and surveillance technologies only become clear once one understands the way they work. Without requiring any previous knowledge in computer programming, this course will explore the basic workings of popular modern algorithms and show students how they are implemented, their potential, and their shortcomings. Students will apply theoretical knowledge from the core courses in engaging with the technical dimensions of emerging and seemingly disruptive technologies. They will produce a research paper that explores the societal implications of an algorithm of their choice. Sessions are organized in a dynamic and interactive way, where the first part of each session introduces the algorithm, and the second allows students to test and explore it.
<li>The different architectures of machine learning algorithms
<li>The broad components of a machine learning pipeline
• The societal impacts of algorithmic design choices.
<li>Apply knowledge from other MA Media Studies courses to the study of algorithms
<li>Evaluate the impacts of selecting and implementing of machine learning algorithms

In this course we provide students with the art historical, theoretical and critical tools to come to terms with the artistic production – the visual arts, especially - of the post-war period. In doing so, students get a better understanding of both the arts and the contemporary. Throughout the course students combine theoretical discussions on the status of art (‘What is Art?’) and the nature of periodisation (‘what is the Contemporary?’) with critical analyses of singular artworks by canonical artists such as Duchamp and Warhol, Nam June Paik and Gerhard Richter, Jeff Koons and Damian Hirst as well as visits to galleries, museums and exhibitions.
<body>After this course, students will be able to:
• Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

Politics is a defining feature of all human societies, yet it takes different expressions around the world. Because of its multi-facetted nature, politics is notoriously hard to define. How, then, can we analyse politics across different countries? Does it still make sense to talk about politics in terms of left and right? Does it matter whether you live in a kingdom or in a republic? How dangerous are populists, really? Can ordinary citizens really change the way they are governed?

This introductory course in comparative politics explores basic concepts of political science across a range of political systems. It will also familiarise you with comparative methodology: does political power lie with a president, prime minister or parliament, and why/how does that matter?

The core of the course will cover the most common political systems. You will learn how to distinguish between regime types, different electoral systems, and key aspects of political behaviour and culture. Finally, key issues structuring politics across the world will be examined: the role of ideology, populism, the relationship between democracy and authoritarianism.
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
• differentiate between a variety of political systems found across the world
• identify political actors and analyse their behaviour
• retrieve and critically analyse sources of political information

column2: Reinforcement Machine Learning discusses unsupervised and reinforcement learning approaches often used to solve management science problems.

column1: The first part focuses on unsupervised machine learning techniques for finding meaningful relations between all variables in a data set simultaneously. In contrast

to supervised machine learning, discussed in a previous course, in unsupervised techniques all variables play similar roles. Therefore, the relationships among all variables must be modelled, whereas in supervised learning only the relationships between the target variable and the features are of direct interest. An important application of unsupervised learning techniques in management is customer segmentation in targeted marketing.

The other main focus of this course is on reinforcement learning, where algorithms are used for sequential decision-making under uncertainty. Here, the focus will be on the design, solution, and implementation of reinforcement learning methods. Sequential decision problems involve a trade-off between exploitation (acting on the information already collected) and exploration (gathering more information). These problems arise in many important domains, ranging from online advertising, clinical trials, website optimization, marketing campaigningand revenue management.
An overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are:
• introduction to reinforcement learning and multi-armed bandits:
• Heuristics: one-step look ahead, regret policies, Thompson sampling
• multi-armed bandit modeling strategies and applications.
This course is a field course in the Tinbergen Institute program for 3 credits in the major econometrics.
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Understand the fundamental building blocks of unsupervised and reinforcement machine learning methods, with special attention to: principal components analysis, clustering techniques (k-means, hierarchical), multidimensional scaling, index-based solutions to multi-armed bandits, one-step look-ahead solutions to multi-armed bandits, Thompson sampling.
Program these methods by translating technical knowledge of a method into their own code in R.
Write a short report in the form of a scientific article.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107443,2022,Urban Data Analytics,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,"['BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. MMJ van Eerd', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark', 'dr. P Nagler', 'dr. Q Ke', 'JM Waardenburg']",,"Inhoud
<body><u>Module 1</u>: This module introduces participants to basic quantitative data analytics and entails the following seven lectures:
• Descriptive statistics (measures of central tendency, measures of spread, correlation).
The statistical software that will be used in this course is STATA 17.

<u>Module 2</u>: This module introduces participants to urban qualitative research and focuses on qualitative data collection and analysis. Covering both theoretical and practical dimensions of conducting qualitative research, it helps the participants to gain methodological skills to design and conduct qualitative research in urban settings. The course is structured around the following themes:
• Qualitative data collection tools (interviews, focus groups, observations, online and offline qualitative data collection).
• Qualitative data analysis with Atlas Ti (types, data preparation and coding, analysis, presentation of findings).

The aim of this course is to equip participants with a basic tool set that will capacitate them to conduct quantitative and qualitative data analyses. More specifically, after following UDA participants will be able to:
• Understand how quantitative and qualitative data analysis differ from each other.
• Identify situations in which quantitative and/or qualitative data analysis provide useful information in an urban context.
• Evaluate the findings for policy recommendation.
• Employ the main tools of descriptive data analysis and visualisation.
• Explain how random sampling is used for hypothesis testing.
• Conduct regression analysis using the ordinary-least-squares method.
• Apply the knowledge in practice using statistical software.
• Understand theoretical and practical aspects of conducting qualitative urban research.
• Apply methodological skills on building qualitative research design, data collection and analysis of qualitative data.
• Critically reflect on qualitative research findings.
• Apply ethical concerns, as well as concerns for validity and reliability in qualitative research.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105372,2022,Urban Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. MJA Gerritse', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort', 'prof.dr. MP Garcia Gomez', 'SJ Vermeulen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

This is a graduate course in Urban Economics. It treats several important topics in modern urban economics. Location and mobility decisions form the central organizing concepts to study cities, commuting, housing markets and real estate, and transport. After building up the urban framework, we examine agglomeration forces, long-run city development, and sustainability and energy efficiency in cities.
The course comes with a hands-on assignment that changes every year. The most recent assignment was from the city of Rotterdam, using large datasets to study spatial inequality.
• To apply economic insights to urban, spatial and location choice decisions
• To understand location choices and to explain how cities and regions’ sizes, wages and land price develop as a result
• To infer the value of amenities and property, based on information from house prices and wages and to comment on policies (transport, housing)
• To explain how cities develop in the long run
• To apply these insights to a real-life case and write a (concise) report

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107269,2022,Urban Economics and Development,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,"['BG Calzada Olvera', 'dr. J Fransen', 'dr. P Nagler', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud
The first part of the track is divided into two modules that are taught in parallel.

The first module covers the areas of urban economic development from a theoretical as well as an applied point of view. In the field of economic development, theories on urban and regional economics, and economic competition and competitiveness will be introduced. Discussions on inequality and entrepreneurship will round up this part of the course. Participants will then be exposed to the topics of innovation, evolutionary economics, sustainable and just economic transitions, place-based economic development policies, and urban labour markets.

Each topic will be covered by a lecture followed by workshops where participants will have the opportunity to discuss concepts and theories in small-scale groups, and to translate these into practical applications working together with their peers. The objective of module 1 is to gain comprehensive theoretical knowledge in the fields of economic development to be able to critically identify and evaluate local and global issues within urban economies, as well as to tackle these by providing workable solutions.

The second module will run in parallel and cover more advanced methods of data analysis for policy evaluation, building upon the core period course ‘Urban Data Analytics’. Students will be introduced to non-linear regression, panel data analysis, binary dependent variable, instrumental variable regression models, and time-series analysis. A major focus of this module lies in the interpretation of results to conduct evidence-based policy analysis.

Weekly lectures and hands-on workshops will introduce the student to both theory and practice. During workshops, students will work with datasets using the statistical software Stata to translate knowledge into practice. Moreover, as the course evolves, students will recognize how different econometric methods are applied within innovation, entrepreneurship, resilience, and regional economic development literature. The objective of module 2 is to gain solid skills and an understanding of quantitative research methods for urban economic analysis with a focus on interpretation
Part 2: Thesis proposal preparation (3rd to 28th of April)

In the second part of the track, students will focus on developing a research proposal for the master’s thesis. Students will build on the research skills and knowledge previously acquired, to prepare a feasible, sensible, and academically relevant thesis proposal. While students are expected to primarily work independently during this part of the track, they will also receive individual guidance during group discussions.

The overall aim of the course is to gain insight into the fundamental urban and regional economic processes that explain sustainable economic development, as well as to develop the ability to analyse and govern these processes in practice.
More specifically, this course has the following objectives:
• Reproduce and interpret theories that deal with urban and regional economic development in a sustainable manner.
• Identify criteria for urban and regional economic development using quantitative methods for evaluation.

• Apply economic and geographical reasoning to analyse sustainable economic development on various spatial scales: from countries and regions, and from neighbourhoods to households and individuals (macro-level, meso-level, and micro-level analyses).
• Apply theories, concepts, and analytical research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.

The UESC master track is comprised of multiple interrelated thematic topics and complemented by a GIS course, workshops and excursions:
• Sustainability and circularity in the context of climate change
• Ecosystems in urban landscapes and social-ecological systems
• Ecosystem based adaptation (EBA) and nature based solutions (NBS)
• GIS-based conceptualization of research questions
• Spatial analysis and GIS tools
• Hands-on application examples (incl. data resources)
• Excursions to two locations (Rotterdam and Amsterdam)
• Workshops (concept development, case study analysis, resilience strategy design)
At the end of the master track, participants should be able to:
• Understand regional climatologies to assess the impact of climate change on the urban environment.
• Illustrate the key concepts, theories, and frameworks behind climate sustainable and resilient cities.
• Evaluate benefits, challenges and limitations of key methodologies, techniques, and tools used by urban practitioners.

The course is organized in 2 distinct modules. Urban governance: starts with an introduction to the complexity of the urban context and then focuses on the changing role of government and other key stakeholders in the governing of and decision making in a city. Students discuss and debate on the key theories that underpin different perspectives on urban governance. The module also looks at the role of local government in the context of decentralisation reforms, and the influences of these reforms on governance. Public Private Partnerships: introduces the concept of Public Private Partnerships (PPP’s) an instrument for urban governance. The students work on a practical case of business planning for PPPs, and use knowledge and skills gained to make key policy decisions on the appropriateness of PPPs in the urban context.

• Urban Governance –this module looks at the nature of cities, and the increasing complexity in cities. It introduces the difference between government and governance, what urban governance is, and the trends in theory and practice on governance. The participants discuss why urban governance is an essential pillar of sustainable development and the different theories that underpin urban governance. Discussions revolve around the current academic debate on the utility of hierarchies versus new public management versus complex decision-making. Participants look at and assess the empirical evidence on both streams of theory and assess the extent to which these approaches have resulted in the outcomes intended at the local level.

• Public Private Partnerships – a mechanism to implement and institutionalize urban policy: Since the 1990’s PPP’s have become an important approach to streamlining cooperation and risk sharing between the public and private sectors, and achieving value for money in service provisions. This module introduces participants to different rationale, objectives and forms of PPP’s. Participants discuss and assess under what conditions PPP’s can be successful vehicles for urban governance and development. They apply a framework to analyse the 'marketability' of PPPs
column2: this framework aids governments to make sound policy decisions related to PPPs.

column2: and understand the relevance of hierarchies, markets and network governance for urban governance.

The Urban Governance Lab helps improve the practical abilities of MUG students to cope with complexity, by imparting basic skills and tools, including co-operation, teamwork, negotiation, co-creating, and network-learning. The Lab presents various ways of dealing with socio-economic and governance problems in a complex urban network system, through a case-based approach. The Lab uses insights from other modules in the course and challenges the participants to use these models and approaches to analyze the cases presented and advise urban practitioners accordingly.

<body data-gr-ext-installed="""" data-new-gr-c-s-check-loaded=""14.1068.0"">The course is organized in 4 different components:

• Urban Governance – decision making in situations of complexity: In this component, we look at theories underpinning urban governance and focus on trends to networked forms of governance. Network governance is seen as an alternative to markets and hierarchies, in particular in situations of increasing complexity and uncertainty. Government is no longer the lead actor in development, but one amongst many. This implies a new role for government, a role in steering and managing horizontal relations.

• Urban Policy – policies for urban development: This component introduces the meaning of ‘policy’ and looks at what makes a policy “urban” as opposed to sectoral. We will discuss the impact of changing concepts (for example, integration, decentralization, participation, neo-liberal approaches) on urban policies, as well as what makes a good policy.

• Urban Planning – this component focuses on the different meanings and interpretations of 'urban planning' and the changing role of the urban planner. This is also in the context of increasing complexity. It highlights trends in concepts, in planning approaches and the shift from traditional land use planning towards more strategic forms of planning.

• Local Government Finance – Local government finance is about the revenue and expenditure decisions of local governments. It covers the sources of revenue that are used by local governments such as taxes (e.g., property, income, sales), user fees, and intergovernmental transfers. It also includes ways of financing infrastructure using operating revenues and borrowing as well as charges on developers and public-private partnerships. Furthermore, local government finance also addresses issues around expenditures at the local level and the accountability for expenditure and revenue decisions, including the municipal budgetary process and capital investment planning.
<body>After the module participants should be able to:

• Describe the differences between network governance theory, traditional public administration and new public management, argue the relevance of the network governance approach in complex decision-making processes, analyse a complex decision-making process applying the core concepts of network governance theory (actor, game, network and network management analysis) and recommend how to improve the performance of networks.

• Describe the meaning, dimensions and objectives of urban policy, as well as the importance of the policy process and tools for implementation, deliberate on the definition of and nature of public interest and who determines it and analyse the quality of policy documents using a set of objective criteria.

• Understand what planning is and its relevance for intervening in urban areas, assess different approaches to planning, the values that underpin them and their influence on the planning outcomes and processes, and analyse the role of the planner and other stakeholders in the planning process.
<li>Discuss the key principles and elements of local government finance
column2: critically reflect upon the theory and practice of the local governments in Infrastructure Asset Management in a given context. Apply economic and financial analysis to investment projects relevant to local governments and incorporate uncertainty and probability in decision analysis and argue, using the principles of economic and financial analysis, how decisions are made in infrastructure investment projects.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107577,2022,Urban History: Rotterdam in Global Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['prof.dr. PT van de Laar', 'R Wervers']",,"Inhoud

The second half of the 19th century witnessed a period of rapid urbanization in Europe. The life of the city dweller, in particular in Europe, became economically, socially and economically dominant. This course orientates on the major transformations:
- Urbanization, the growth of cities and the shaping of the modern global city
- The port city as specific city (second city, shock city) and its relationship to the global city
- The planned modern city and ideal models on urban planning
- Cities as places of migration and superdiversity
- Urban visual culture, urban icons and the mediatisation of the city
- Urban heritage, public history and the role of the city museum

Rotterdam, originally one of the many typical Dutch commercial medieval cities, showed a spectacular growth in the 19th century. Rotterdam became the working city of the Randstad conurbation and turned into a world port after the Second World War. The modern urban history of Rotterdam – considered to be the most dynamic city of the Dutch metropolis since 1850 – is used as a case study to discuss the impact of 19th and 20th century urban transformations.

<body>Cities have played a significant role in the transformation of the world and today a majority of the world population lives in cities. Many scholars relate this urban revolution to a new round of globalisation. However, globalisation is a much longer-term historical process. This course focuses on 19th and 20th century’s urban transformation and gives an introduction on global urban history, using Rotterdam as a case study.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107268,2022,Urban Housing, Equity and Social Justice",Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,"['dr. MMJ van Eerd', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark', 'dr.ing. AA Ayala Aleman']",,"Inhoud
<body>Housing is understood as more than a roof over one’s head.&nbsp
column2: It not only represents the most valuable asset a household strives to access during its life cycle, but also, more often than not, a process tainted by political, social and economic exclusion and injustice.

column1: The access to adequate housing is a perpetual global challenge. Shifting housing paradigms, translated into policies and strategies, have provided valuable learning experiences of what does and what doesn’t work. However, the reality is that the housing challenge in majority of urban areas, especially in the Global South, persist and is ever growing. The housing challenge manifest itself through a vicious cycle of inequality and injustice in the redistribution of housing opportunities, leading to housing poverty and the proliferation of slums.&nbsp

The master track therefore focuses on evaluating the complex process of housing in relation to equity and social justice. From the housing perspective, the course defines equity as the role that policies and institutional frameworks have in ensuring that everyone has access to housing by recognizing people’s needs for housing according to their circumstances. Social justice, narrowed down to the attainment of equity in the process of realizing adequate housing for all, represents a more complex theoretical debate. It deserves a closer look at the role that public and private sectors, the market and the society have in defining what constitutes justice in housing.&nbsp
column3: Our starting point is that social justice in housing is concerned with the universal realization of housing as a basic need and a human right. It strives to evaluate the redistribution of housing-related benefits and the procedures behind the realization of adequate housing for all.

column1: From planning of cities to urban environmental concerns, migration, and urban issues such as urban poverty, gender inequality and gentrification, the approaches taken to address the housing challenge can certainly be both driving and restraining forces. Adequate housing has perhaps the most relevant role in addressing these urban challenges. The course objective is to apply the principles that defines adequate housing, namely housing accessibility, affordability, availability, acceptability, and adaptability. These principles are universal and not mutually exclusive. The understanding and application of these principles are the starting point to evaluate housing policies and approaches. Therefore, throughout the course, case study analysis of policies and approaches to housing is used with the aim to question the status-quo in which these policies and approaches take place
column2: to critically reflect on what the outcome in practice of such policies and approaches is
column3: and to start devising the best possible mechanisms that foster accessible, aﬀordable, available, acceptable, and adaptable housing for all.

column1: The main objective of the master track is to evaluate how housing policies and approaches address the housing challenge.
To achieve this objective at the end of the course, participants should be able to argue how the process of housing affect urban households, particularly the poor, and their neighbourhoods by:
• Understanding how the housing sector works from a governance and economic point of view.
• Analysing the principles of adequate housing, namely availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability and adaptability in different housing policies and approaches.
• Critically reflecting on the application of the principles of housing availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability, and adaptability for realizing adequate housing and housing rights.

• Evaluating to what extent current approaches to formal and informal housing address the housing challenge in relation to the provision of adequate housing, equity, and socio-spatial justice (i.e., housing justice).
• Designing housing policies that would ensure housing justice and adequate housing for all.

In line with the unique feature of the MSc Programme, participants will be able at the end of the course to link the theory that supports different housing approaches to its translation into practice through the development of different skills, such as case study analysis, group work, communication skills, role playing, and the practical application of different assessment tools such as stakeholder analysis, housing needs assessment and climate change adaptation strategies in housing.

<body>In both popular imagination and academic discussions, we are regularly told that the future is urban. Rapid and new forms of urbanization are changing what cities are and what it means to live in city-regions. This course is an invitation to travel to some cities in Latin America, Africa, and Asia with the aim of cultivating a comparative perspective on urbanization processes. Through this intellectual journey, we will absorb the lessons that cities in the non-West impart about categories and methods for understanding urban conditions. Along the way, we will encounter 5 key themes which animate contemporary urban research: Housing
column5: and City Nights. In wrestling with the major social problems which assail cities and the hopes they offer its inhabitants

This course discusses challenges related to sustainable urban development from a complexity perspective. By the end of the course, participants will be able to apply a complexity perspective to analyze how cities across the world in highly diverse contexts produce a wide range of wicked problems related to sustainability and resilience. These wicked problems may relate to unsustainable housing, land, infrastructure, economics, environment, climate change, planning and social development.
The course is offered in three parts which are closely interwoven:

• ComplexCity: This part conceptualizes the evolution of cities from the perspective of complexity, showing how wicked problems related to sustainability and resilience emerge and endure. It forms the theoretical base of the course, comprising lectures, workshops, discussions, and self-study. Participants thus gain knowledge on the main concepts of the course (complexity, sustainability, resilience), their trends and application in diverse urban contexts, and their interlinkages. In workshops, they will practice how wicked problems emerge and endure.

• Gaining Land Use Transactions (GLUT): GLUT is an intensive pedagogical game that applies a complexity perspective to dynamic urban land markets. The game illustrates how land markets and stakeholder decisions shape cities over time and how that affects urban sustainability.

• Individual deepening: from the onset of the course, participants choose a particular wicked problem in a city that they would like to describe and analyse based on theory and the GLUT game. This enables participants to bring in their own interest, knowledge, and focus. It culminates in an individual paper on a wicked sustainability or resilience problem in a city and an infographic, which visualizes how the wicked problem has emerged and endured.

column1: The final grade will be determined at the end of term 4 .
Theme: Urban transformations in a globalising world

Cities are the most dominant social organisation in the world since the beginning of the twentieth century with more than half of the world’s population living in urban centres. This process will continue with astonishing speed during the next decades. Scientists believe that more than 70 per cent of the global population will be urban by the middle of the twenty-first century. A historical approach to recent and less recent urban transformations can help us to understand the impact of these changes. However, the urban form takes different shapes all over the world: the urban spread of Los Angeles is different from the dense living in Hong Kong’s skyscrapers or the historical centre in Amsterdam. This means that urban transformations need to be understood in their local context. The rising globalisation does not only remind us of the necessity to study the variety in urban configurations, but it also urges scientists to look at the growing diversity within cities. Our current global ages pose large challenges regarding inequality, political participation, social and cultural diversity, claims on public space, housing, environmental footprints, transport, energy consumption and health. This workshop allows students to study urban developments from a historical perspective.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October
• Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107368,2022,Urban and Transport Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. J. van Ommeren (VU), Prof. J. Rouwendal (VU) and Dr H. Koster (VU)

We introduce and apply the key concept of spatial equilibrium, where distance between agents, i.e. transport costs, play a fundamental role in their behavior (location choice, labor supply, productivity). For example, we explain the role of agglomeration, the role of residential amenities, and the value of time of travel. Conceptual theoretical models are introduced and examined which are the basis for empirical work and are used as a guidance for welfare and policy analysis. Theoretical concepts are backed up with empirical studies.

Travel costs (notably the value of time) are key for understanding the spatial equilibrium of workers and firms within the city. In the transport lectures we discuss the dominant empirical approaches to estimate this value (including discrete choice analysis). We also pay attention to the impact of transport infrastructure on urban development.

Social interaction within cities and neighborhood effects as well as urban policy will receive due attention. We will, for instance, discuss the welfare impacts of place-based policies. The course schedule will be as follows:
1. Introduction: Equilibrium within cities (including the monocentric model)
4. Urban transport economics I (value of time, reliability)
5. Urban transport economics II (urban road and public transport infrastructure)
This follows the chapters in Glaeser, E. (2008).</body>

De jaarlijkse wedstrijd van de VAR (Verenging voor Bestuursrecht) bestaat uit het indienen van een beroepschrift en een verweerschrift en het geven van een pleidooi. Deelname aan dit vak vindt in teamverband plaats onder intensieve en persoonlijke begeleiding van deskundige medewerkers van de sectie bestuursrecht. Bij de eerste bijeenkomst wordt gestart met het bestuderen van de casus en komt het team tot een taakverdeling. Vervolgens worden data en tijdstippen voor verdere bijeenkomsten in overleg met de deelnemers besproken en vastgesteld. In de periode januari tot en met april doe je als team onderzoek ten behoeve van het opstellen van het beroepschrift (half maart) en het verweerschrift (half april). Van april tot aan de wedstrijddag staat het voorbereiden op het pleiten centraal. De pleitnotities worden geschreven en becommentarieerd en er vinden pleittrainingen plaats.
A. Samenwerken bij het aanpakken van een juridisch vraagstuk.
B. Analyseren welke juridische vraagstukken in een casus zitten.

Gedurende dit vak maken studenten kennis met diverse (academische en professionele) vaardigheden die nodig zijn binnen hun academische en professionele carrière. De drie onderdelen van het vak (studievaardigheden, literatuuronderzoek en communicatievaardigheden) bouwen op elkaar voort en worden verder toegepast binnen de parallelle theoretische vakken gedurende de bachelor. Tevens worden studenten aangespoord op hun handelen te reflecteren en staan zij stil bij vragen als: welke vaardigheden heb ik verworven? Hoe verloopt mijn leerproces? Waarom zijn deze vaardigheden belangrijk voor mijn academische en professionele ontwikkeling?
Dit vak is opgedeeld aan de hand van drie hoofdthema’s die zijn afgeleid van de drie belangrijkste overkoepelende academische en professionele vaardigheden, namelijk:

1. Studievaardigheden: de basis van alle academische vaardigheden zijn studievaardigheden. Binnen dit onderdeel van het vak ligt de focus voornamelijk op het lezen van academische teksten, het samenvatten en structureren van de inhoud en het schrijven volgens wetenschappelijke conventies. Als student leer je zo hoe diverse wetenschappelijke teksten zijn opgebouwd en hoe je met de juiste leesstrategie gemakkelijk tot de kern van de tekst kunt komen. Tot slot is er aandacht voor het geven en ontvangen van feedback, een belangrijke vaardigheid in de eigen academische en professionele ontwikkeling.

2. Literatuuronderzoek: Binnen dit onderdeel worden de lees- en schrijfvaardigheden uit het eerste thema direct toegepast aan de hand van een literatuuronderzoek. Studenten leren hoe zij relevante wetenschappelijke literatuur verzamelen, analyseren en verwerken tot een literatuuronderzoek. Extra aandacht voor de vaardigheden analytisch denken en schrijven zijn van belang binnen het ontwikkelen van een eigen academische stem.

3. Communicatievaardigheden: In het laatste onderdeel van dit vak leer je hoe je communicatie kunt afstemmen op verschillende doelgroepen en hoe je dit overtuigend doet. Dit doen studenten middels diverse opdrachten en presentaties. Als professional dien je niet enkel te lezen of te schrijven voor een wetenschappelijk publiek, maar is het belangrijk je boodschap naar verschillende doelgroepen te kunnen vertalen.
Na afloop van dit vak zijn studenten in staat om…
- De structuur van wetenschappelijke tekst te doorgronden
- Diverse leesstrategieën te onderscheiden en toe te passen
- Structuur aan te brengen in wetenschappelijke teksten
- Te schrijven in een wetenschappelijk verantwoorde stijl
- Op wetenschappelijk verantwoorde wijze te refereren naar verschillende bronnen
- Te benoemen waarom feedback belangrijk is, hoe je goede feedback kunt geven en wat je kunt doen met ontvangen feedback
- Te benoemen waarom reflectie belangrijk is, hoe je reflecteert op je eigen voortgang en hoe reflectie kan helpen bij je zelfontwikkeling.
- Via uiteenlopende kanalen wetenschappelijke literatuur te zoeken
- Gevonden literatuur te selecteren en beoordelen op hun relevantie
- De gevonden literatuur te gebruiken voor een eindpaper
- Een onderzoeksvraag op genuanceerde wijze te beantwoorden door middel van een literatuuronderzoek.
- Te weten hoe verschillende doelgroepen benaderd moeten worden
- Verschillende vormen van communicatie af te stemmen op diverse doelgroepen
- De uitgangspunten van een goede presentatie te kennen
- Een helderen en aantrekkelijke presentatie te geven.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106134,2022,Valuation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Rajamani', 'dr. TEM Paaso']",,"Inhoud

Understanding what drives the valuation of companies is essential not only from an investor’s perspective but also in one’s role as a manager, security analyst or merger advisor. The goal of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary for performing discounted cashflow valuation of firms from first principles. The course will also touch upon multiples-based valuation techniques.&nbsp

The first sessions of the course will focus on the adjustments necessary for identifying value relevant cashflows from reported earnings and other available accounting information. In the following sessions we will discuss how to identify the drivers of growth (as well as the limits to growth) so as to make economically meaningful forecasts. This will be followed by an estimation of the cost of capital for firms which involves among other things, the estimation of firms’ business and financial risk. Finally, we will learn how to incorporate these inputs into valuation models appropriate to the firm-specific context (for example the cost of capital approach or the adjusted present value approach) to come up with an estimate of firm value.

To provide hands on experience, in the workshops we will apply the theories discussed each week to estimate different valuation inputs to complete a real-world valuation exercise by the end of the course.</body>
At the end of this course students will be able:
• To obtain exposure to, and familiarity with, the financial statements of companies.
• To be able to make requisite adjustments to financial statements for estimating value relevant cashflows.
• To be able to forecast future cashflows, to determine the cost of capital, and to apply discounted cashflow valuation techniques appropriate to the context of the firm.
• To understand the assumptions underlying the various valuation methodologies (discounted cashflow models, and valuation multiples) and the differences / similarities therein.
• To appreciate the role of judgment in financial accounting and analysis.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105568,2022,Value Based Health Care,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. M de Mul', 'drs. ZLR Kaplan', 'E.M. Verheul', 'G Steinmann', 'M. van der Linde', 'N Salet, MD MSc', 'N. van Leeuwen', 'S Allers', 'T Gigengack', 'Z.L.R. Kaplan']",,"Inhoud

column2: the population ages and treatment opportunities constantly increase, controlling costs while maintaining quality is one of the major challenges in the health care sector. Value-based Health Care (VBHC) was introduced by Harvard Professor Michael Porter as a way to address this challenge. VBHC focuses on maximizing the value and minimizing the costs of care delivery, amongst others by paying provides based on outcomes and inducing competition between providers to increase efficiency.
column4: interest in VBHC as a way to increase value for money in health care has grown rapidly. Encouraging healthcare providers to deliver high-value care has become a focal point in health policy. Also, in the Netherlands, many hospitals are trying to implement VBHC, and like elsewhere, they face several challenges and there is also criticism. Different aspects that relate to VBHC (integrated care, shared decision making, outcome differences in outcomes between health care providers, value-based payment) will be introduced during this course. You will learn on the theory principles. This will be combined with guest lectures from practitioners (for example from the Erasmus University Medical Center and Zilveren Kruis) that have tried to implement (elements of) VBHC in practice.

column1: For example, measuring outcomes plays a central role in VBHC, but when comparing outcomes between providers several methodological issues should be taken into account. You will learn on the validity of outcome measures as indicators of quality of care and which issues complicate between-provider comparisons. Moreover, various types of value-based payment models have been proposed to replace common volume-based payment methods. New models to how health care providers are paid come in many different flavors, stimulating different dimensions of value, such as quality of care, coordination of care across providers and settings, cost-consciousness, and health outcomes. You will learn about the main drivers of value-based payment reform.
<body>Specifically, after this module students will be able to:
• explain and reflect on the main elements (of the theory behind) VBHC
• explain and reflect on the main criticisms on VBHC
• analyze and reflect on the main barriers and facilitators of VBHC implementation
• describe prominent VBHC initiatives in practice, and derive key lessons
• formulate future challenges with respect to VBHC
• empirically study and report on a VBHC initiative in a hospital
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106336,2022,Values of Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. C Dalla Chiesa'],,"Inhoud

This course studies the values of culture based on the cultural economic perspective. In contrast to the conventional economic approach, the cultural economic perspective utilizes insight from both sociology and cultural studies to study the values of culture. We start from the fact that individuals and organisations in the cultural sector try to realize values beyond money and self-interest. One of the crucial resulting differences is that between the value and the price of cultural goods and services. We pay specific attention to the different spheres in which artistic activities are realized and analyse the different logics according to which these spheres operate. Topics that are discussed include valuation and valorisation of artistic activities, the notion of quality of cultural goods, the economy of attention, cultural entrepreneurship, and cultural goods as social goods.
You can clearly distinguish between the economic perspective and the cultural economic perspective.
You can identify and make sense of the different values people are seeking to realize in the cultural sector, and how these change over time.
You can distinguish and describe the most important spheres in which individuals and organizations seek to realize the values of culture.
You can analyse the different institutional logics of the spheres, and how these can give rise to conflicts about the relative importance of different values, and how they are best realized.
You can critically analyse and reflect on how a cultural organisation or entrepreneur seeks to realize the values of culture.</body>

column5: strangers. On the other hand, humans differ in their morals and their conceptions
column6: of well-being. The possibility of being cheated by other humans is so pervasive
column7: and primitive that it is hard-wired into our psychology. Even very small children are
column9: Values, Welfare and Cooperation is an exploration of philosophical questions that
column10: arise from these discoveries from economics, psychology, and other sciences.

column2: course begins with the nature of moral value. How can humans cooperate? A commonsense
column3: answer is that we are coordinated by objective morality, but anthropologists
column4: and historians have found many intercultural moral differences. Is morality
column5: objective? Is moral disagreement an inherent part of morality? Can it always be
column6: resolved by objective methods? Must moral disagreement be different from scientific
column7: disagreement? What barriers does moral disagreement present to objectivity

column1: The next part of Values, Welfare and Cooperation is about cooperation. Can human
column2: society function via self-interested individuals agreeing to conventional constraints&nbsp
column3: on their behaviour? Or must cooperation have deeper psychological or intellectual&nbsp
column5: The course finishes with the issue of welfare. How should we assess whether cooperative&nbsp
column6: behavior in some context is good or bad? A common approach in modern&nbsp
column7: societies is to answer this question by looking at whether institutions for cooperation&nbsp
column8: help or hinder human “welfare”. But what is welfare? This question raises a&nbsp
column9: surprising number of philosophical and economic questions.

column1: By the end of this course, students can:
1) Understand the principal theories in metaethics.
2) Explain the major theories of social cooperation..
3) Assess the main theories of social welfare.
4) Critically engage with these ideas through structured and sophisticated argumentation.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105192,2022,Vector Calculus (econometrics),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. R Spliet'],,Inhoud
Concepts: eigenvalues, eigenvectors, orthogonality, projections, diagonalization, quadratic forms, vector spaces, inner products, norms, distances and vector differentiation.

Computational skills: determine eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalizations, orthogonal bases, orthogonal decompositions, QR factorizations, spectral decompositions, optimal values of quadratic forms and vector derivatives.

This course uses knowledge of FEB21019X Matrix Algebra and FEB21021X Analysis, and is required for FEB21009X Linear Programming, FEB22003X Introduction to Multivariate Statistics, FEB22006X Nonlinear Optimalisation, FEB22017X Finance en FEB22004X Econometrics 1.
• Acquiring conceptual knowledge of linear algebra and vector calculus.
• Acquiring computational skills of linear algebra and vector calculus.
• Acquiring insight in abstract structures at the required level for Econometrics beyond doing merely computations.
• Acquiring skills in proving theorems in matrix algebra and vector calculus.

<body>Compulsory attendance of at least 70% of the tutorials (this obligation does not apply to HBO/WO pre-master students, Erasmus Colleges students and students who have already achieved a valid - registered in OSIRIS - but insufficient course result).</body>

Kennis: Eigenwaarden, eigenvectoren, orthogonaliteit, projecties, diagonalisatie, kwadratische vormen, vector ruimten, inwendig producten, normen, afstanden, en vector differentiatie.

Dit vak gebruikt kennis van FEB21019 Matrix Algebra en FEB21021 Analyse, en is nodig voor FEB21009 Lineair Programmeren, FEB22003 Inleiding Multivariate Statistiek, FEB22006 Non-lineair Optimaliseren, FEB22017 Finance en FEB22004 Econometrie 1.

In het vak Vennootschapsbelasting wordt de Wet op de vennootschapsbelasting 1969 integraal besproken. Tijdens de colleges worden de grondslagen van de vennootschapsbelasting behandeld.
Hierbij komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

De regels met betrekking tot de fiscale winstbepaling worden bekend verondersteld: hier wordt op ingegaan voorzover daarvoor specifieke regelingen in de Wet op de vennootschapsbelasting 1969 gelden. Het vooraf succesvol doorlopen van het vak Inkomstenbelasting B wordt aanbevolen.

• Student is in staat om de Wet op de Vennootschapsbelasting binnen de andere belastingwetten te plaatsen.

De Wet op de vennootschapsbelasting wordt voortdurend aangepast om enerzijds Nederland concurrerend te houden als vestigingsland en anderzijds te voorkomen dat de grondslag waarover belasting wordt geheven, wordt uitgehold. In deze dynamische ontwikkeling van het vakgebied wordt inzicht gegeven in:
• de relatie tussen de vennootschapsbelasting en de inkomstenbelasting in verschillende landen
• de Nederlandse belastingplicht voor in Nederland gevestigde lichamen en voor in het buitenland gevestigde lichamen
• de bijzondere voorschriften voor de fiscale winstbepaling van lichamen (ter aanvulling op het vak Winst)
Bij het onderzoek naar bovenstaande onderwerpen wordt veelal een relatie gelegd met het ondernemingsrecht en het internationaal en Europees recht.</body>

Vennootschapsbelasting wordt geheven over de door lichamen (zoals de NV en de BV) behaalde winst. Doelstelling van het vak Vennootschapsbelasting is de student een kader te bieden waarmee hij onderstaande vragen kan beantwoorden:
• Is een lichaam onderworpen aan de vennootschapsbelasting?
• Zo ja, hoe wordt de winst van een belastingplichtig lichaam bepaald?
• Tegen welk tarief wordt de belastbare winst van een lichaam belast?

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104809,2022,Verandermanagement,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']",,"Inhoud

Deze module geeft allereerst aan de hand van het boek van Burke en aanvullende literatuur een inleiding in de belangrijkste inzichten en theorieën uit de literatuur over verandermanagement. Daarbij is toepassing van deze literatuur op de specifieke situatie van publieke organisaties uiteraard van groot belang voor een bestuurskundige opleiding. Tijdens het college zal dan ook uitgebreid ingegaan worden op de consequenties van deze context.

Uiteraard draait het bij verandermanagement niet alleen om theorie, maar juist ook om praktijk. Deze praktijk krijgt gestalte door gastcolleges van externe deskundigen en door de inbreng van alumni die in het verleden onderzoek naar veranderkundige vraagstukken van publieke organisaties hebben verricht.

Bij de toetsing gaat het enerzijds om het toetsen van kennis (door middel van een MC tentamen), anderzijds om het vermogen om deze kennis toe te passen. Dit laatste zal gebeuren aan de hand van een takehome tentamen waarin zal worden gevraagd om te reflecteren op één of meerdere casussen.&nbsp

Verandermanagement bouwt voort op Publieke Organisatie en Verandering (B2) en sluit aan op de mastervakken Publiek Management en Organisatie, S-HRM en HRM in de Publieke Sector: Capita Selecta. In het atelier van HRMV bestaat de mogelijkheid om de kennis door middel van een groepswerkstuk verder te verdiepen.
Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:
<li>de kernbegrippen en verschillende benaderingen op het gebied van verandermanagement uitleggen
<li>deze begrippen en benaderingen toepassen op publieke organisaties
<li>reflecteren op de voor- en nadelen van een door een (publieke) organisatie gekozen veranderaanpak
<li>een advies uitbrengen over de aanpak van een organisatieverandering&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107650,2022,Verantwoord leiderschap in organisaties,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'F Torres Nadal, MSc']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105863,2022,Verbindend management van interactief bestuur,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'dr. MJ Nederhand']",,"Inhoud

Een belangrijk kenmerk van veel hedendaagse bestuurlijke vraagstukken is dat zij de grenzen van verschillende organisaties, domeinen en sectoren doorkruisen. Naast deze complexiteit is het ook speelveld van sturende actoren pluriformer geworden en hebben traditionele instituties van de representatieve democratie aan gezag ingeboet. In de afgelopen jaren zien we daardoor in toenemende mate vormen van interactief bestuur ontstaan waarin overheden in interactie met maatschappelijke partijen, private partijen en burgers publieke besluitvorming of dienstverlening vormgeven. Geregeld ontstaat dit op initiatief van de overheid. Denk hierbij aan het organiseren van participatie in besluit- en beleidsvorming. Maar steeds vaker zien we ook dat maatschappelijke partijen, burgers en ondernemers zelf initiatieven ontwikkelen (zelforganisatie) binnen het publieke domein en daarbij al dan niet samenwerking met de overheid zoeken. Denk hierbij aan burgerinitiatieven, bewonersbedrijven en sociale ondernemingen. Tegelijkertijd spelen de organisatorische en institutionele grenzen die met interactief bestuur doorkruist worden nog steeds een belangrijke rol. Die staan soms op gespannen voet met vormen van interactief bestuur en inter-organisatorische samenwerking. Het managen van deze interactieve vormen van bestuur is daardoor een enorme uitdaging. Dit vak focust op de verbindende rol van individuen (micro perspectief) in het verbeteren en waarborgen van de legitimiteit en effectiviteit van grensoverschrijdend werken in de publieke sector.

Waar in vorige vakken kenmerken en theorieën van beleids- en sturingsvraagstukken zijn besproken op voornamelijk meso- en macro niveau, richt dit vak zich specifiek op het individu (micro-perspectief): verbindende personen in interactief bestuur. In het vak Sturing van Complexe Vraagstukken is de rol van boundary spanners al even aangestipt. Dit vak gaat daar dieper op in en onderzoekt de barrières en managementuitdagingen waarmee verbindende personen binnen verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur geconfronteerd worden. Zowel de skills, uitdagingen en strategieën van verbindende personen als de effectiviteit en legitimiteit van hun handelen staan centraal. Onderdeel van het vak zijn meerdere groepsopdrachten en een simulatie waarin studenten leren om een onderbouwd en concreet advies te geven aan managers die te maken hebben met interactieve bestuursprocessen.
Na afronding van het vak zijn studenten in staat:
- Om de complexiteit en achtergrond van verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur te doorgronden
- Om kritische voorwaarden te formuleren voor effectief en legitiem interactief bestuur
- Om uit te leggen wat verbindende personen kenmerkt en welke rol ze spelen in het managen van interactief bestuur
- Om barrières en managementuitdagingen van verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur te analyseren
- Om een onderbouwd en concreet advies te kunnen geven aan managers die te maken hebben met een specifiek interactief bestuursproces en/of project.
<body>The mandatory book can be purchased as an ebook, at a lower cost, through the publisher: Edward Elgar</body>

<body>Het vak Verbintenissenrecht bouwt voort op het vak Inleiding privaatrecht uit B1
column2: het vak biedt zowel een verdieping als een verbreding van de daar aangeboden stof. Verbintenissen komen voort uit contract of uit de wet. Het verbintenissenrecht omvat aldus het contractenrecht en het onrechtmatige-daadsrecht. Het doel van dit vak is primair om kennis op het gebied van het verbintenissenrecht op te doen en om deze te verdiepen. Daarnaast leert u juridische problemen te analyseren, te argumenteren en oplossingen te verwoorden.

column1: <body>Na dit blok kun je aan de hand van de wet en relevante jurisprudentie:
• beoordelen of in de fase voorafgaand aan de totstandkoming van een overeenkomst verplichtingen zijn geschonden en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.
• beoordelen of een rechtshandeling dan wel een overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de inhoud daarvan is.
• beoordelen of sprake is van (on)bevoegde vertegenwoordiging en wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.
• beoordelen of de grenzen van de contractsvrijheid zijn overschreden en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat daarvan de gevolgen zijn.
• beoordelen of een beroep kan worden gedaan op (een beding van) de algemene voorwaarden.
• beoordelen of sprake is van niet-nakoming van een (koop)overeenkomst en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.
• beoordelen of sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen welke schadeposten voor vergoeding in aanmerking komen.
• beoordelen of sprake is van kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen welke schadeposten voor vergoeding in aanmerking komen.
• beoordelen of sprake is van derdenwerking van contracten en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.

• beoordelen of een beroep kan worden gedaan op (een beding van) de algemene voorwaarden.
• beoordelen of sprake is van niet-nakoming van een (koop)overeenkomst en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.
• beoordelen of sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen welke schadeposten voor vergoeding in aanmerking komen.
• beoordelen of sprake is van kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen welke schadeposten voor vergoeding in aanmerking komen.
• beoordelen of sprake is van derdenwerking van contracten en, indien dat het geval is, beoordelen wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn.

Gegeven de scheve verdeling van gezondheid worden normatieve aspecten van gelijkheid besproken. Welke gelijkheid moeten we nastreven? Wanneer is sprake van een rechtvaardige verdeling van gezondheid? Iedereen heeft recht op gezondheidszorg, maar hoe ver gaat dit recht? Vanuit bepaalde normatieve uitgangspunten is in Nederland (nationaal en lokaal) en internationaal beleid geformuleerd om de scheve verdeling van gezondheid tegen te gaan. De wijze waarop deze doelen tot stand komen en vervolgens vertaald worden in beleid vormt de aanleiding om kennis te laten maken met de beleidscyclus. Vervolgens wordt bediscussieerd wat de mogelijkheden zijn van de Nederlandse overheid om hun beleidsdoelen na te streven.

Via wet- en regelgeving kan de overheid het stelsel van gezondheidszorg vormgeven om meer gelijkheid na te streven. Zowel de nationale situatie als de internationale (Europese) situatie wordt besproken. Via en binnen het stelsel van zorgverzekeringen worden keuzes gemaakt om ongelijkheid al dan niet op te heffen (bijvoorbeeld samenstelling pakket, aanpak van wachtlijsten). Tevens kan men op de scheve verdeling van gezondheid ingrijpen door rechtstreeks risicofactoren aan te pakken, door bijvoorbeeld verschillende vormen van preventie. Gezondheidsbevordering is een belangrijk onderdeel van preventie.

Vervolgens wordt met de student bediscussieerd wat het effect van het beleid is en hoe dit kan worden vastgesteld. De bepaling van ongelijkheid in termen van ziektelast, gebruik cijfers en financiering van de zorg toont o.a. effecten op rechtvaardigheid en gelijkheid van verschillende stelsels. De effecten van preventie en gezondheidsbevordering worden toegelicht aan de hand van voorbeelden over laag sociaaleconomische groepen en groepen met een migratieachtergrond.

Helaas blijft een ongelijke verdeling van gezondheid altijd bestaan. Beleidsmakers nemen niet altijd de meest rationele beslissingen op grond van de cijfers uit onderzoek. Evidence-based health policy is meer een mooie term dan een succesvolle beleidsstrategie. Verschillende perspectieven tonen dat andere mechanismen van invloed zijn in de totstandkoming van beleidsbeslissingen, in alle fasen van de cyclus.

Aan het einde van het vak wordt weer teruggegrepen op het begin: de ongelijke verdeling van gezondheid. Aan de hand van onderbouwde stellingen wordt het spanningsveld tussen gelijkheid, rechtvaardigheid en schaarse middelen om doelen te bereiken bediscussieerd.

<body>In het vak wordt vanuit verschillende disciplines naar vraagstukken van verdeling gekeken. Een belangrijk leerdoel richt zich op het multidisciplinaire kennen en kunnen: De student kan vanuit verschillende disciplines (sociaal-medische wetenschap, economie, recht en beleidswetenschap) met behulp van theoretische modellen en concepten casussen (verdelingsvraagstukken) analyseren en is in staat beleidsmakers te voorzien van beargumenteerde aanbevelingen. &nbsp
